**43. Careless Burial of Bones**
The ancient way of gathering bones for burial was earnest,
Yet subtle distinctions within prove hard to discern.
Let Magistrate Zhou’s case serve as warning—
Dry bones, though senseless, repaid kindness on their own.

In Nanhui, it was customary to leave coffins unburied. Some were covered with straw, others walled with bricks, left along the inner and outer city walls or scattered across the fields. After many years, as descendants grew ever poorer, the coffins rotted and split, exposing the remains.

In the *yimao* year of Xianfeng (1855), my father served as *er yin* of this county. One day, strolling through the outskirts, he saw the exposed remains and was moved with sorrow. He consulted with *Xuebo* Bao Shanfu, and together they donated their salaries to bury them. At that time, I had just returned home on leave from the military camp, and my father instructed me and *Mingjing* Li Yinxiang to personally lead laborers in gathering and interring the bones. Yinxiang then told me: "The difficulty of collecting bones lies in the slightest carelessness inviting disaster. During the Qianlong era, Magistrate Zhou, upon assuming office here, was grieved by the sight of exposed remains. He donated his salary to purchase land and had the bones gathered for separate burial. However, the overseer proved incompetent, allowing the laborers to collect them haphazardly—failing to distinguish between male and female, mixing remains indiscriminately, scattering fragments, and even placing this shin with that elbow in the same urn, or combining a woman’s foot with a man’s skull in a single coffin."

Moreover, there were coffins still sturdy and intact, or only partially decayed, which could have been repaired. Yet those tasked with burial would forcibly split them open, rifling through their contents. What began as a virtuous act of "burying *zhi* and covering *ge*"—where *ge* denotes dry bones and *zhi* putrid flesh—nearly became a tyranny of "tomb-raiding and grave-plundering." (As Chen Lin’s *Proclamation to Yuzhou* for Yuan Shao decried: Cao Cao appointed a *Colonel of Grave-Plundering* and a *Captain of Tomb-Raiding*, leaving no remains unexposed in their wake.)

Upon completion of the work, the overseer fell ill. In his sickness, he saw countless men and women—some missing an arm, others limping on one foot; some men with dainty, bound feet, others women of imposing, masculine stature. Still more bore gaping holes in their backs or chests, cleft lips, or shrunken eyes—no telling how many there were.

The wraiths encircled his bed, hurling abuse—so vexed was the sick man by their clamor that he shut his eyes, only for them to pinch his ears and pluck his brows, tormenting him beyond endurance. Every prayer and supplication proved futile. Soon after, the magistrate himself fell ill, and in his sickness, he too heard the cries of grievance. The clamor of voices was too frantic to discern clearly, but the gist was this: bones had been jumbled, remains wantonly scattered, coffins pried open without cause. They had petitioned the gods, they said, and now demanded the magistrate descend to the netherworld to set things right. In the end, he and the overseer perished in quick succession. Of all who took part in this labor, not one survived the span of a few years.

Master of Sitting Among Flowers remarked: "To do good carelessly is to invite retribution from the unseen realm. One might think this enough to dissuade men from the very thought of virtue—but those who harbor the *intention* of doing good yet act with reckless haste, without sincerity or diligence, bring greater harm than those who do nothing at all. Worse still is to bask in the hollow reputation of virtue while inflicting real ruin upon others. If the dead possess any awareness, how could they not ache with sorrow?"

Case Forty-Four: The Magistrate of Chengde – How Could a National Celebration Outweigh Unrepaid Famine?
To Open the Granary Was a Crime He Would Bear Alone
Yet the People’s Straightforward Dao Still Endured as in the Three Dynasties
Their Love and Veneration No Less Than That for the Mulberry of Duke Shao

The late Mr. Shi, father of Shi Daosheng—Surveillance Commissioner of Heng-Yong Circuit in Hunan—had served as a *xiangkui* magistrate of Chengde County in Fengtian. (The second to fifth place in the provincial examination were called *xiangkui*.) A drought had struck the county: no wheat in summer, no grain in autumn. Famine and displacement followed—nine out of ten households suffered. (Famine: pronounced *jin*. The *Analects* commentary states: “When grain does not ripen, it is called *ji*; when vegetables do not ripen, it is called *jin*.” Here, “famine and displacement” means displacement caused by famine.)

That year, the nation celebrated a grand occasion (referring to major imperial weddings or the emperor’s birthday). The chief minister (pronounced *fang*, interchangeable with *bing*; here, referring to the grand councilor) did not wish to trouble the emperor’s sagely consideration with a localized disaster. The officials of the auxiliary capital all complied with his intent. Mr. Shi repeatedly petitioned for relief, but his requests were rejected three times. They even cited the case of fraudulent relief in Gansu as a dire warning to intimidate him. (Intimidate: pronounced *chu*, meaning to frighten.)

Enraged, Mr. Shi opened the Ever-Normal Granary in full to feed the starving. When others tried to stop him, he laughed and said, “If I am charged with unauthorized distribution of granary grain, the worst I face is confiscation, imprisonment, and repayment upon term’s end—my punishment would be mine alone. As the magistrate of this county, how could I hesitate to trade my life for the salvation of ten thousand people?” After the distribution, he submitted a memorial confessing his offense.

His superiors were furious and swiftly impeached him. (Impeachment: as previously annotated in the chapter on Madame Yan.) In the end, he was charged with embezzlement and sentenced to execution. (Embezzlement: pronounced *shi*, meaning deficit. Execution: as previously annotated in the chapter on Jealousy and Treachery.) He fell ill and died in prison. (Illness: pronounced *yu*. The phrase is from the *Book of Han: Annals of Emperor Xuan*.)

At the time, the magistrate’s wife had already passed away, and his son—the future provincial inspector—was still young. None among his colleagues inquired after them. Adrift, they wandered to Liaoshen, then drifted into the capital. At fifteen or sixteen, the boy worked as a hired laborer in a tavern to support himself. One day, several patrons were drinking at the tavern when the young man overheard their accents and recognized them as men from Chengde. He mimicked their speech to engage them in conversation. The patrons exclaimed in surprise, “Are you not our neighbor?” He replied, “No, my family is from south of the Yangtze, but I grew up in your homeland, so I can imitate your way of speaking.” “Then what is your surname?” they asked. “My surname is Shi,” he answered. The men all rose to their feet and said, “There was once an official who served as father and mother to our county—how do you address him?” The young man’s tears welled up, and he choked with sobs, unable to speak.

The patrons ceased their questions and said, “After the second watch tonight, when the tavern closes, come find me at such-and-such an alleyway—do not fail to keep the appointment.” The young man agreed. When evening came, he made an excuse and went. He had not taken more than a few steps from the tavern door when a man in formal attire awaited him on the road and asked, “Are you Master Shi of Chengde?” “Yes,” he replied. The man then helped him into a carriage. Upon reaching the alleyway, those awaiting his arrival lined the road without end. As they entered the gate, every door stood wide open, and the lanterns blazed with dazzling brilliance. No sooner had he alighted from the carriage than over a dozen men in formal attire supported him as he ascended the hall, clustering around him as he took the seat of honor. They prostrated themselves in rows and addressed him, saying, “We have sought you for years! That you should have drifted into such straits—this is all our fault.”

"Fortunately, the spirit of your late father guided us to seek you in the capital, and now we have truly met—could this be anything but Heaven’s will?" At that moment, the young magistrate was still a child when his father had passed, and he had been seven or eight years old at the time. Having drifted in destitution for so long, he was suddenly honored and revered by these men of rank, so unexpected that his eyes widened in stunned silence, unable to utter a single word.

The guests then explained to him: "Your father distributed grain to relieve famine, willingly bearing the weight of capital punishment to save tens of thousands of lives. We are all among those disaster-stricken people who once ate that grain. Year after year, as the harvests ripened, we longed to repay his great virtue. We learned that your father had perished in prison and heard that you, his son, had wandered through Liaodong and Shenyang. We dispatched dozens of men to search everywhere, but no trace could be found. Yesterday, the abbot of the local temple dreamed that your father had arrived to take office and revealed your whereabouts to him. Thus, we were able to come to the capital to seek you."

Thereupon, they bathed him, dressed him in new robes, and prepared the main bedchamber to lodge him. The next day, they set out wine and music, taking turns to offer toasts in celebration.

A certain official, the Dao Overseer, also arrived that day. Addressing the assembly, he said: "My entire family of eight had no steady livelihood. When sudden famine struck, none but your late father could have saved us. In the year my own father passed away, he took my hand and said: ‘Magistrate Shi brought this extraordinary calamity upon himself to rescue the people, scattering his family like stars. You are fortunate to have earned an official rank—if you fail to repay his kindness, you are no son of mine.’ I have borne this charge for years now, and it weighs upon me day and night, yet I have found no means to fulfill it."

This day, fortunately, we behold the young master’s noble bearing and striking appearance, and know he is destined for prominence and renown, to carry forward his late father’s unfinished aspirations. I beseech you all to entrust him to my care. In the future, when the young master achieves his meritorious fame, I alone shall take responsibility for it.” Thereupon, the assembly entrusted him to the care of Chengde.

Previously, after the master’s passing, his family had hastily prepared his burial, abandoning the coffin in a neglected shrine. Now, the people of Chengde selected a proper site for his interment and also established a dedicated shrine in his honor, endowing it with lands for sacrificial offerings. On the very day the Prefect arrived for inspection, the shrine’s construction was completed, and all marveled at the coincidence. They then settled the young master within the shrine, where his clothing, food, and daily needs were overseen by an elder, all provided from the communal funds—always abundant, always generous. Furthermore, they engaged a renowned tutor to instruct him. Yet the Prefect, having endured hardship from a young age, began his studies late; though he labored diligently, his progress was slow. After several years of reading, while he gained a rough understanding of literary meaning, he remained utterly lost in the art of examination essays.

The Daoist master, having heard of this, summoned him to the capital and arranged for him to serve in the Bureau of Strategy and Tactics. He also brokered a marriage for him with a family of noble lineage and promoted his reputation among the high officials. Ultimately, through the Daoist master’s influence, the young man obtained an official post and soon thereafter joined the military campaign in the southern lands of Chu. There, he roused himself to diligence and discipline. Within a few years, he rose to the rank of Prefect and was later recommended for promotion to the position of Provincial Inspector.

Upon petitioning to retire, he was heard to have become a man of Chengde. The Master of the Flower-Adorned Seat remarked: “In governing the people, he spared no effort in saving the multitudes—truly, he did not betray the trust of being a parent to the people! Yet while he rescued those beneath the meanest eaves, the prison’s inmates alone met their doom. His spirit-chariot was forever abandoned in the overgrown shrine, and his young children were reduced to menial drudgery.”

Long in such straitened plight—how could those who do good not tremble with fear? Yet in death he became Yama, King of the Underworld, and in life he left behind a legacy of love. The people of that city, having buried Zhu Yi in Tongxiang, then sought the young master in the capital and Luoyang, moved by dreams that bridged waking and sleep, and bore word of him home. Raised from the muck and mire, he was set upon the heights of azure clouds; his clothing and food were made abundant, his household made whole. They nourished him with poetry and books, guided him with teachers and guardians, spurred him toward merit and renown—until at last he spread his wings in the open sky, lashed his steed upon the royal road, and the scion of a house once noble regained his former station. The favor bestowed was deep indeed, and the recompense was full. Though the love of the sweet pear-tree alone might have stirred their innate devotion, their reverence for virtue and praise of benevolence endured long, ever seeking repayment through his son before they could rest content. In this land, the customs of loyalty and righteousness—might they yet uphold the ways of old?

A certain scholar from Wanjiang—Wanjiang being Anhui—was traveling to Jinling for the examinations. Delayed by contrary winds, he moored his boat along the riverbank and went ashore for a stroll. Wandering into a village, he saw several people conferring on the road, sighing and lamenting as though at a loss for any recourse. Faint weeping reached his ears. After walking a few paces more, the sobs grew nearer, their tone steeped in grief and resentment. He then encountered another group wringing their hands and stamping their feet, their distress no different from the first. Only one among them, standing to the left, remarked, “If only some great-hearted soul would generously provide the cost of a coffin, today’s affair might yet be resolved for both sides.” The others replied, “That is precisely the difficulty—how easily you speak of it!”

The scholar stepped forward, cupped his hands in inquiry, and asked, “Why do you grieve so deeply? May a passing traveler hear the cause?” The group turned to the man on the left, saying, “Surely this is the very man of great compassion you spoke of! Why not tell him?” The man replied, “How can we be certain?” He then explained the matter in full:

“This village is home to a single extended clan. A cousin of mine has died, leaving behind a widow who has steadfastly maintained her chastity. Their son is but a few years old. The widow serves her parents-in-law with filial devotion, spinning and weaving to provide for their needs. A month ago, her father-in-law fell ill, and in seeking physicians and purchasing medicines, she exhausted every resource. Yesterday, he passed away. With no means to obtain a coffin, the family is now forced to consider selling the widow to pay for his burial. She grieves that she cannot remain chaste to the end, yet she mourns the thought of leaving her parents-in-law, who cling to her in their dependence, and she cannot bear to part with her child. From yesterday until now, her sorrow has caused her to faint several times. As for the rest of us, years of famine and drought have left us penniless. We lament that such a woman of loyalty and filial piety should be lost to us, and so we sigh in despair.”

The scholar, moved, asked, “How much silver is needed to secure a coffin?” The group replied, “Thirty taels would suffice.” The scholar then invited them aboard his boat, produced his silver, and said, “I carry forty taels for this journey. I shall give you thirty and keep ten, which will be enough to see me through the examinations.” The villagers were deeply touched; some wept, exclaiming, “Truly, this is a man of great compassion!”

Just then, the wind shifted favorably, and the boatman hoisted the sail, eager to depart. The scholar hurriedly ushered the villagers ashore. In their haste, neither side had time to inquire after names, and they parted with cupped hands and words of gratitude.

Upon reaching Jinling, the scholar found himself short of funds. He borrowed from a fellow townsman trading in the city, thus avoiding destitution. When the examinations began, he entered his assigned cell to find an old man already seated there, motionless. Surprised, he asked where the man had come from, and the old man replied, “I am your cellmate.” The scholar was perplexed, for the cell seemed spacious enough for both to share a cot without crowding. They exchanged names and hometowns, discussed the examinations, and conversed on literature and scholarship, finding mutual delight in their exchange.

As they prepared for sleep, the old man said, “Rest well; do not concern yourself with me.” At the fourth watch, the examination topics were distributed, and the scholar saw the old man seize his brush and write with swift precision. Attempting to rise, the scholar felt as though pressed down by a nightmare and fell back into a stupor. When he awoke the next day at noon, the old man had vanished. Examining his own examination paper, he found it already filled with draft writing. Astonished, he unfurled it to read—only to discover prose of grand depth and poetry of refined elegance, all four compositions complete, truly the work of a top-ranked candidate.

Marveling, he asked the cell attendant, “Where has the old man who shared my cell gone?” The attendant replied absently, “He has left.” The scholar did not press further. Though he and the old man had been strangers, how had the latter composed such masterful work for him? He read and reread the text, praising it without end. Taking up his brush to compose his own thoughts, he could not produce a single original word and so copied the draft in full.

When he entered the examination cell for the second session, the old man was already there, greeting him with a smile: “It seems we share a karmic bond from a past life, for we meet again in the same cell.” The scholar expressed his gratitude for the first session’s assistance, reproaching the old man for leaving without a word. “Why did you vanish without a trace?” he asked. The old man laughed and said, “In a former existence, I owed you several compositions—this was known to the spirits. Why thank me? Tonight, simply rest well and ask no further questions.” The scholar followed his advice.

The next morning, the old man had vanished once more, yet all five classical texts were complete. The same occurred in the third session. After the examinations, the scholar sought the old man’s lodgings, but no one knew of him. Fearing the strangeness of the matter, he dared not speak of it to others.

Upon returning home, as he prepared to cast off from the dock, a man suddenly rushed toward him from the shore, begging to board the boat. It was the old man from his examination cell. Clapping his hands, he exclaimed, “Truly, we share a karmic bond—we meet again!” Overjoyed, the scholar hurriedly welcomed him aboard and asked about his belongings. The old man replied, “I am alone, with nothing to my name.” When asked where he lived, he said, “You will know soon enough.”

As they reached the previous mooring, the old man pointed to a village on the shore: “That is my home. Please, do not scorn my humble dwelling—will you not visit?” With that, he hastened ashore. The scholar followed quickly, but as he entered the village, the old man moved swiftly, vanishing from sight. Hesitating in confusion, he encountered the man who had earlier sought donations for a coffin. The man bowed by the roadside and said, “Sir, have you returned?” The scholar urgently asked for the old man’s name and lineage. The man gasped in shock: “He was my clansman’s uncle, who passed away over a month ago—the very man you once generously funded for burial.” The scholar exclaimed in astonishment, “What do you mean? This gentleman shared my examination cell for all three sessions!”

"After the examination, he again shared my boat on the return journey, seeing me ashore and watching as I entered the village. Now this—could I have encountered a ghost?" The man grew even more alarmed: "Then it must truly have been my uncle’s spirit! My uncle was indeed a *su ru*—a scholar of profound learning—renowned for his vast knowledge and literary skill. Yet he languished for years in the examination halls, dying with his aspirations unfulfilled. In early autumn, my aunt once dreamed of my uncle coming to bid her farewell, saying, ‘I am bound for Jinling to repay the kindness of the coffin and burial. Through his literary blessings, I shall at last reveal that my decades of failure in the examinations were not for lack of merit—*it was not the fault of the battle.*’"

"'Now, sir, what you have encountered aligns precisely with the dream—how extraordinary! My uncle’s wife and daughter-in-law were deeply moved by your kindness to the bone. They repeatedly urged me to wait respectfully by the riverbank, hoping to have the good fortune of inviting you for a visit. Since this strange coincidence has occurred, would you accompany me to their home to settle the matter?'

The scholar thus went with him. Upon arrival, they found a thatched hut with a wattle gate, its walls bare and desolate. Before the hall hung plain white curtains and white candles, with a portrait suspended high. The man who had commissioned the coffin pointed to the scholar and said, 'This is the spirit of my uncle.' Drawing nearer, the scholar saw it was indeed the elderly candidate from the examination hall.

He then recounted in detail their encounter in the hall and how he had drafted the examination essay on his behalf. The man went inside to report, and his uncle’s wife, daughter-in-law, and orphaned son all came out to kneel in gratitude. The scholar, moved, modestly declined, saying, 'I am deeply indebted to your late husband’s noble virtue. My small act has been repaid a hundredfold—my gratitude will never fade. If I should pass the examination, I shall share my wealth and rank with you all, for I dare not betray such great kindness.'

With that, he bowed before the spirit tablet to express his thanks and took his leave."

The announcement of the examination results came, and indeed, he achieved high honors. The following year, he passed the metropolitan examination and was appointed magistrate of Wu. He continued to provide for the family of the elderly scholar, summoning his son to the yamen and engaging a renowned tutor to instruct him. Later, the son succeeded in his studies and entered the Hanlin Academy.

The Master of the Flowery Seat remarked: *"Goodness born of utmost sincerity is true goodness. When this scholar divided his gold to purchase the coffin, did he harbor even the slightest thought of seeking fame or expecting repayment? His grief in weeping was enough to deepen his emotion; the filial piety and integrity of the deceased were enough to command his respect. Thus, from genuine compassion, great mercy arose—truly, he was a man of perfect sincerity! In the Nine Springs, gratitude transcended the barrier of the unseen realm; by composing the examination essay on his behalf, he secured success in the spring and autumn examinations. A small act met with abundant reward—why should men hesitate to do good?"*

**Parallel Prose (Four-Six Style), Cold Armor:**
*A chance lodging held a fate unseen,*
*Yet greed for gain led to fields and gardens bought.*
*Who knew a wolf’s heart would meet a tiger’s lung?*
*By New Bridge’s river, grievance was wrought.*

In the eastern countryside of Qu’e (Qu’e being Danyang County), there lived a man named Leng Jia, poor and of no virtue. One evening, a traveler sought lodging at his home and bestowed upon him generous gifts. After several days, the guest became intimate with Leng’s wife, coveting her wealth. Leng, aware of this, feigned ignorance and allowed it. Soon after, the guest departed, only to return half a month later. He produced gold, pearls, silks, and other treasures in great abundance, giving a portion to Leng to purchase fields and a house, while entrusting the remainder to his wife, instructing her to bury it in a pit. Thereafter, the guest came and went frequently, and Leng grew prosperous through this association. Over time, his comings and goings aroused suspicion, and Leng realized he was a bandit, though he bore no ill will toward him.

Later, the guest vanished for months. One day, a messenger arrived in haste, delivering a letter from the guest to Leng. It revealed that he had attempted to rob the household of a great gentry family in Wu, had been captured, and was now imprisoned in Wu County, his confession already recorded. Fortunately, he was not the ringleader, and with clever planning, he might yet escape death. He urgently begged Leng to bring silver to Suzhou and arrange matters on his behalf, his pleas filled with sorrow and desperation.

Upon receiving the letter, Leng secretly consulted his wife. Fearing that sparing the bandit’s life would bring lifelong trouble, they set out for Suzhou under cover of night. When Leng met the bandit, he deceived him, claiming he would devise a plan to secure his release and promising a full report. In secret, however, he bribed the authorities to solidify the bandit’s guilt, shifting him from an accomplice to the principal offender, and had him executed at once.

More than a year after the bandit’s death, Leng entered the city and walked along the New Bridge riverside with several companions. Suddenly, he cried out, *“There he comes!”* Then, *“He’s thrusting a fork at me!”* He shrieked, collapsed to the ground, and died.

**Postscript**

Perusing the accounts in this book, one sees how aid rendered in a moment of dire urgency may yield boundless retribution. Many admire such deeds yet lament the rarity of such opportunities. Yet the ways of doing good are innumerable—what one lacks is not the means but the heart.

The rewards of accumulated virtue follow as closely as a shadow clings to form. To benefit oneself, one must first benefit others. Nowhere are urgency and hardship more acute than in the ravages of fire and flood. Often, when the Fire God rages unchecked, the poor and humble are suddenly struck by calamity, their suffering so grievous that the eye cannot bear to witness it. Or when floodwaters surge to the heavens, homes are swept away, and the desperate wails of the doomed rise in chorus—left with no choice but to await death.

For those who wish to sow virtue, such moments present the finest of opportunities. One should investigate the households afflicted by disaster and, in secret, dispense silver to offer relief. A few coins may save a single life; a few dozen may preserve an entire family. The wealthy, of course, ought to give generously, but even those of modest means should strive to persuade others to contribute, joining together in the cause. How limitless, then, would their merit be!

To rescue lives below is to move the heart of Heaven above. The Dao of reward for virtue and retribution for vice never fails. The Five Blessings and Three Abundances may be attained without effort—why, then, regret the infrequency of such occasions?

Truly, extraordinary good deeds beget extraordinary merit. The Way of Heaven delights in reciprocity, a truth verified time and again throughout the ages. Thus, I append these few lines to the end of this work, earnestly exhorting the benevolent gentlemen of the world.

**Preface**

*The Record of Seated Blossoms and Ripe Fruits* is a work by my friend, Wang Diaosheng. Diaosheng, a renowned scholar of western Zhejiang, followed his official post to Jiangzuo, repeatedly serving as a key aide in prominent yamen, his reputation resounding throughout the literary world. He took what he had absorbed in daily life and committed it to writing. Those unfamiliar with Diaosheng may be daunted by the breadth of his observations, deeming the book a mere source of witty tales to provoke laughter. Yet those who know him say: “This is Diaosheng’s苦心 to save the world, using his pen as his tongue. Even the morning bell that awakens from dreams or the precious raft that guides through the ford of delusion cannot surpass it.”

Since the *Nine Hundred Tales* of Yu Chu, fiction from the Han and Wei dynasties onward has favored extravagant and fantastical words, with narratives spun from trivial matters and reckless speech proliferating daily. Such works, like the frivolous banquets of *Fuxiu* or the absurd tales of *Qi Xie*, are shallow and lack substance, wild yet without foundation. Even when compiled into volumes, they do little to edify the world. Song scholars, by contrast, excelled in chronicling dynastic affairs, court rituals, and the deeds of the past, often serving as sources for historians.

In our present dynasty, *Strange Tales from Liaozhai* by Pu Liuxian has been widely emulated. Its brushwork rivals that of Sima Qian and Ban Gu, showcasing the utmost skill of a literary master. Yet half of its accounts involve ghosts and foxes, while the rest are interspersed with playful anecdotes, leaving discerning readers with some regret. During the Qianlong era, the eminent scholar Ji Xiaolan of Hejian, endowed with vast and refined talent, compiled the *Siku Quanshu* catalog. In his spare time, he produced *Luanyang’s Summer Records*, *Thus Have I Heard*, and *Huai Xi’s Miscellany*, which circulated widely across the land. His works, though meticulous in textual research and argumentation, are accessible only to those deeply learned and thoughtful. By contrast, *baiguan* novels—from scholars to farmers and merchants—are universally read with delight. Thus, embedding moral lessons within their narratives ensures their easy dissemination and reception. Truly, the morning bell that awakens from dreams and the precious raft that guides through delusion find their embodiment in Xiaolan.

Now, Diaosheng, possessing refined talent, aspired to advance through imperial examinations but repeatedly stumbled at the gates of the examination hall, his ambitions thwarted. With no alternative, he entered officialdom as a minor clerk. The lament of talented men serving as petty officials is a sorrow shared across the ages. This book’s narratives are concise and elegant, its judgments deliberate. Moreover, it adheres to factual accuracy, verifying details through extensive inquiry, avoiding baseless fabrications or repetitive clichés. Whether it rivals Xiaolan’s work, I dare not say. Yet its苦心 to save the world only deepens my admiration for Diaosheng.

Recently, Diaosheng has resided in my hometown, and our interactions have grown closer, our bond deeper. Entrusted with the task of proofreading, I, despite my humble abilities, offer this preface.

*Written in the fourth month of summer, the year Ding Si of the Xianfeng reign, by Jing Lvji of Danyang.*

---

**Phonetic and Explanatory Notes on the Preface to *The Record of Seated Blossoms and Ripe Fruits***

*The Record of Seated Blossoms and Ripe Fruits* presents a tapestry of karmic retribution, blending exhortation and admonition—truly a virtuous work. Yet it has long lacked phonetic annotations, much to the regret of its readers. I wished to provide them but hesitated due to my own inadequacies. Perhaps, given the vastness of the world, there are like-minded individuals who might undertake this task. For now, I can only wait.

In the year *Wu Yin*, while residing in Shanghai, I gathered with fellow scholars to pool resources for printing virtuous books. Among them was a volume I had long wished to annotate: *The Record of Seated Blossoms and Ripe Fruits*. Earlier, Mr. Hu Mengxiang had also been a guest here. In his spare time from studies, he took up this book and provided phonetic and explanatory notes. Morning and evening, he researched and verified, completing the task over two seasons. His苦心 is evident. Moreover, he chose not to reveal his name, attributing the work to the “Woodcutter of Vulture Peak,” a choice that further demonstrates his noble intent.

From this, we see that the reservoir of goodness throughout history remains ever-present in the world. I dare not claim Mr. Hu’s heart mirrors my own. Yet his love for virtue aligns with my long-held, unfulfilled aspiration—what fortune it is to find such resonance! Now, Mr. Hu has suddenly passed away, unable to witness the completion of this book. Truly, this is a great pity. As for the precision of his research and the accuracy of his philological explanations, they are evident to all who read them—what more need be said?

*Written in the third month of spring, the year Wu Yin of the Guangxu reign, by the Master of Wenzhu Studio in Shanghai.*

---

*The Record of Seated Blossoms and Ripe Fruits* is the work of Mr. Wang of Renhe, who, with the extraordinary talent of a blind left eye, chronicled the true events of the Xianfeng and Daoguang eras. He vividly depicted what he had seen and heard in daily life, rendering scenes with such clarity that they seem to unfold before the reader. How could this be merely a rigid exercise in promoting virtue?

Yet in its meticulous recounting of events, the principle that "goodness leads to prosperity, while evil brings ruin" is made manifest without the slightest deviation. Those who read this book may first find it strange and take delight in it, but soon recognize its truth and feel a chill of fear. Its power to uphold the moral order and transform human hearts operates invisibly yet irresistibly, turning the course of things beyond all bounds.

From ancient times to the present, sacred scriptures, worthy biographies, and books of admonition and encouragement have filled countless chests and boxes. Yet though their solemn pronouncements and earnest exhortations are more than sufficient to strike deep fear into the heart, over time they become mere objects of idle curiosity. Some dismiss them as distant and irrelevant, others as stale and hackneyed, and most consign them to the highest shelves, never to be opened again. For the more urgent the admonition, the greater the aversion it breeds; the stricter the supervision, the more vehement the resistance.

This book alone, with its fresh and striking approach, invites eager circulation, while its vivid accounts of karmic retribution awaken the innate goodness of human nature and sever the roots of selfish desire. Its subtle yet profound transformative power defies full description. In its artful use of indirect remonstrance, Mr. Wang’s craftsmanship is truly masterful, and his intentions deeply earnest.

We, his peers, all recognize the great significance of this book for the moral order and the human heart, and thus hasten to entrust it to the printers, that it may be transmitted for generations to come.

*Respectfully inscribed by fellow scholars in the twelfth lunar month of the year Ji Chou, the fifteenth year of the Guangxu reign.*

**General Principles**
1. This book records only events of admonition and encouragement from the past thirty years, as witnessed or heard by the author. Matters from more distant times, already documented by earlier worthies, are not redundantly included, to avoid the charge of plagiarism or mere repetition.
2. This book aims to be accessible to both the refined and the common, intelligible even to women and children. Thus, the prose is deliberately detailed and clear, neither overly concise at the risk of obscurity nor excessively novel at the expense of authenticity.
3. As karma demands that one’s deeds be recounted in person, and as the ancient teaching of concealing faults while praising virtue remains luminous, this compilation records the full names and native places of those whose good deeds merit inclusion, provided they can be verified. For evil deeds, only the events are described, without naming the individuals, so that filial descendants need not sigh in shame while reading.
4. All events in this compilation are based on factual evidence; none are fabricated or follow the fantastical style of the *Qi Xie* or *Zhi Guai*. However, as many accounts derive from friends’ and acquaintances’ retellings, discrepancies may arise. Should any inconsistencies be found, we humbly ask knowledgeable readers for their forbearance.

**Notes on Pronunciation and Exegesis**
1. The annotations in this book aim to ensure its wide circulation. Wherever a phrase or character might pose difficulty, explanations are provided in detail, so that even those with only basic literacy may grasp the meaning with ease.
2. For citations from various sources, if the full context is necessary for clarity, only the title and passage are noted. If the citation is a well-known phrase, only its source is indicated, for the sake of simplicity.
3. For citations whose origins cannot be immediately traced, the phrase is marked “source unknown,” followed by a tentative explanation based on the compiler’s understanding. If the meaning remains obscure, it is left unannotated, awaiting the insights of learned scholars.
4. If a citation has been fully annotated in a previous section, later references simply note “see annotation in [section name].”
5. Characters requiring phonetic or semantic clarification are annotated in every section where they appear. No omissions are made on the grounds that a character has been annotated earlier, so that readers may understand the text even when consulting it at random. However, if a character appears multiple times within the same section, its annotation is not repeated.
6. In annotating difficult characters, earlier works of exegesis (such as the *Tang Yun*, *Ji Yun*, *Zheng Yun*, and *Yun Hui*) are followed strictly, without substituting homophonous characters. For example, the character 嗫 in 嗫嚅 is glossed as 日涉切 in the *Ji Yun*, and here we retain the pronunciation of ; the character 魇 in 梦魇 is glossed as 幺琰切 in the *Yun Hui*, and here we retain the pronunciation of . Yet such annotations may still prove cumbersome for readers. Thus, in such cases, we replace them with more familiar characters to better serve the original intent of the annotations.
7. For difficult characters in the level tone where no common equivalent exists, a character from the rising, departing, or entering tones with a similar pronunciation is chosen, following the rules of *xieyun* (rime-matching). Though not all readers may distinguish the four tones, and some may still read a rising-tone character as level or an entering-tone character as departing, the pronunciation remains sufficiently close to avoid gross error—far preferable to glossing a difficult character with another difficult one.
8. Book titles, original texts, and difficult characters within original annotations are not further glossed. Explanatory notes likewise avoid difficult characters wherever possible.

**Case in Point: Filial Son He**
*Filial piety stands foremost among virtues—its rewards are no lie,*
*Else how could such a paragon of manhood arise?*

*He scorned reward-silver and the theft of fame,*

**I**
In Yangxian, the Venerable Father of Provincial Governor Wan Limen—Master Yanzhai—was a *xiucai* in his youth. Though his family was very poor, he was upright and never took what was not his, yet bold in doing what was right. When others faced urgent hardship, he would go to great lengths to aid and comfort them, even if it meant sullying his own reputation. Once, while serving as a private tutor in the countryside, he set out on foot at year’s end to return home. Midway, he encountered a middle-aged woman walking and weeping. Struck by her distress, he asked what was wrong, but she remained silent. Pressing her, she snapped: “Wayfarers each have their own cares—why trouble strangers with endless talk?” Seeing her words sharp but her expression sorrowful, he reassured her: “I do not ask idly. If you are in dire straits, tell me; perhaps I can help.” The woman then said: “My husband is the village headman. He has fallen short of thirty-odd taels of official silver, and now lies imprisoned, daily subjected to the rod and cudgel as they demand repayment.”

**III. Ten Taels for a Life**

*The diviner’s precision, the physiognomist’s marvel—*
*Who knew of the life saved at Jiangjin?*
*The *jieyuan* was but a ghost beneath crumbling walls,*
*For fortune and misfortune have no gate—one invites them oneself.*

A certain eminent scholar in his youth suffered extreme poverty, often going days without kindling a fire. In the year he sat for the provincial examination, a diviner in his village—renowned for his uncanny accuracy—declared that before the White Dew festival, he would die an unnatural death. The scholar was deeply troubled. As the examination date neared, several classmates urged him to join them, but he demurred, citing the diviner’s warning and pleading lack of funds. Among them was a certain Mr. Wang, wealthy and of noble character, who had long been on good terms with the scholar. He insisted on the journey, saying, “Why heed such empty words? If you fear destitution, let me take care of it.” With that, he pressed ten taels of silver into the scholar’s hand: “Use this for your family’s needs. For travel expenses, you may ask freely—I will provide.” Moved by his generosity, the scholar joined the group. They set out several days after the Beginning of Autumn.

Upon reaching Jinling, they heard of a physiognomist at Cheng’en Temple whose judgments were often strangely accurate. His chamber was as crowded as a marketplace. The scholar and his six fellow lodgers went together. The physiognomist surveyed them all: one was a *lin* scholar, another a *zeng*, a *fu*, a *jian*; some enjoyed the blessing of both parents, others mourned their loss—his assessments were unerring in every case.

The scholar, moved by her plight, summoned the copper and examined it—indeed, it was copper. Just then, the gold Wang had given him happened to be in his sleeve. Thinking of his impending death, he mused, *What use is gold to me now?* So he secretly exchanged it for the copper and said to the woman, “You nearly died in vain. This is true silver—why call it copper?”

The woman flared with anger. “Every silversmith I went to said it was copper! Why would you deceive me?”

“Not so!” he replied. “Those silversmiths took advantage of you as a woman. Come with me, and they will not dare call it copper again. If it is truly copper, you may still choose death later.”

She followed his advice, and together they walked three or four *li* before reaching the silversmith’s shop. The scholar produced the silver, and the smith declared it genuine. They visited several more shops, and all confirmed it was silver. Overjoyed, the woman exclaimed, “Fortune favored me in meeting you, or I would have perished in error!” She took the silver, bowed in gratitude, and departed.

The scholar hurried back to his boat, but by then the sun had set, and dusk had deepened into twilight. Before he had gone a *li*, he lost his way, with no one to ask for directions. As he wandered hesitantly, he suddenly saw a cluster of buildings ahead. Drawing nearer, he saw crumbling doors and ruined walls—it was an abandoned temple. With no other choice, he sheltered beneath its eaves to await dawn.

As he sat in the desolate night, he thought, *If a fox spirit or ghost should seize me, this will be my deathbed.* Yet exhaustion overtook him, and he soon fell asleep. In his half-dreaming state, he heard voices shouting to clear the way. Looking up, he saw the temple hall ablaze with light, attendants standing in solemn rows, and a king seated at a table—dimly, he recognized the figure as Lord Guan. Suddenly, he heard the deity say, “Today, by the river, someone saved five lives. We must examine this person and grant them due reward.”

A purple-robed official stepped forward, holding a document. “The local earth god has just reported: it was a scholar from such-and-such a county.”

Lord Guan ordered the register of fortunes checked, along with the autumn examination roster. Another official in embroidered robes presented a ledger. “This man’s fate is spent; he is destined to die tonight at the hour of *zi*, crushed beneath the temple’s collapsing wall.”

“How can we encourage goodness if this is so?” the deity mused. “His fate must be rewritten. Yesterday, the Wenchang Palace informed us that the *jieyuan* of this year’s Jiangnan examinations was stripped of his title for defiling a maiden. Let this scholar take his place.”

Someone else spoke: “The gold he used came from Wang, who gave it freely in righteousness. Since this act allowed the scholar to achieve merit, we should trace its source and record Wang as well.”

“Well said,” Lord Guan replied. He ordered the ledger checked: Wang was to rank fifty-third in the middle-level examinations of a future year. The embroidered-robed official stepped forward. “The current fifty-third candidate is to be penalized for slander and deferred for one examination. The replacement has not yet been decided by the Wenchang Palace. Let Wang take his place.”

As the scholar listened intently, a sudden shout near his ear cried, *“Go! Go!”* Startled awake, he found himself still crouched beneath the eaves. All around was darkness, nothing to be seen—only the sound of crumbling plaster pattering from the wall. He staggered to his feet and fled.

Just as he hurried out, the wall suddenly collapsed, crashing down precisely where he had been sitting. Thus, he stood upright and waited until dawn. A Star Lord Descends with Banners and Streamers,
Yet Two Affairs Deceived a Widow and Cost Me the Title of Provincial Graduate

Repeatedly accumulating karmic entanglements, repeatedly stripped of rank,
A full-cheeked, square-jawed man bearing a noble countenance—

In my remaining years, I was a native of Yin County in Zhejiang. At my birth, an extraordinary fragrance filled the room, and rosy clouds illuminated the sky. **V. The Scholar Wu**

*True kin indeed are only brother and brother-in-law—*
*Would they risk their lives to save his whole household?*
*Sealed in his chamber, he grieved the stolen primacy,*
*Yet owed a debt deeper than even his examination master’s grace.*

Wu of Yixing, a scholar renowned in the academy, sat for the examinations time and again, yet never succeeded. In Changzhou, many were the great clans—such as Prime Minister Lü Gong, Chief Examiner Yang Tingyi, Minister Zhao Shenqiao, and Grand Coordinator Pan Siju—whose descendants achieved successive degrees in the imperial examinations, their literary legacy unbroken. It is said that during the campaign to suppress the Miao rebels, Minister Qian, then serving as Minister of Justice and military advisor, joined the expedition. After the rebel chieftains were executed, the commanding general sought to slaughter all adult males while sparing the young and weak. Consulting Minister Qian, he declared resolutely: *"Evil seeds must not remain!"* Thus, all were put to death, not a single child left alive, and the Miao bloodline was extinguished. Soon after the army’s return, Minister Qian passed away, his son followed in death, and many of his grandsons were afflicted with disabilities. The Qian ancestral sacrifices ultimately ceased.

VIII. A Beggar’s Blessing
*Returning the Gold*

This beggar was fine timber indeed—
To win so much yet crave not a grain!
A jade found its buyer with joy unfeigned:
Wife, wealth, and children came all in train.

Jia Ayu was a native of Yangxian. In his youth, he begged for food in the village and often sheltered in a local earth-god shrine outside the city. One New Year’s Eve, as dusk fell, he noticed a roll of indigo cloth on the ground. Upon picking it up, he found a woman’s garment wrapped around a packet of silver—some thirty taels in all. Overjoyed, he then thought: *"I am but a beggar—what use have I for this? The one who lost it may yet come to harm in despair."* So he sat and waited for the owner to appear.

After some time, a middle-aged woman emerged from the city, wailing and searching the ground. Knowing her to be the rightful owner, he called out to her. Seeing only a beggar, she paid him no heed and wept all the more bitterly. Ayu said: *"What are you searching for? I have sat here long and may have seen it."* The woman then told him of the lost garment and silver, adding: *"My husband was imprisoned for unpaid taxes. I sold our daughter to raise the money—now it is gone, and I have nothing left but death."* Ayu asked about the color of the garment and the wrapping of the silver; all matched. He immediately produced them and returned them to her.

Overcome with gratitude, the woman offered him a portion of the silver in thanks, but he steadfastly refused. That night, as he lay in the shrine, he saw the hall ablaze with lamps and candles. *"Surely it is not yet dawn—why would worshippers come so early?"* Suddenly, he heard voices from the hall: *"Today, a beggar did not conceal lost gold but saved a couple from death. His merit is great—he deserves a blessing."* Another voice replied: *"This man is fated to remain a beggar and live only to thirty."* The first voice said: *"We should petition the Eastern Peak to amend his register of blessings and grant him a wife and children to encourage virtue."* Then came the command: *"First, bestow upon him a chest of silver."* At once, someone placed a large chest before Ayu, saying: *"The gods above have granted this to you."*

He awoke in ecstasy—only to find the shrine as dark as before. As he stretched and rose, his foot struck something with a metallic clang.

At dawn the next day, Ayu begged and received a great many cakes. After eating his fill, he took six coins to the Long Bridge and gambled with the sugar vendors, winning every match. After besting ten or more vendors, he had won a thousand coins. He then went to the gambling den and won again. From morning till dusk, he amassed tens of thousands of coins. Nearby, an old merchant surnamed Jia ran a noodle shop beside the Long Bridge. Whenever Ayu begged for food or money, he would go buy noodles, and the old man had long taken pity on him. That day, Ayu entrusted all his winnings to the shop. The next day, he gambled again and won without fail. After four or five days, his coins had grown to over a hundred thousand. Suddenly, he reflected: *"The money I win at gambling is all ill-gotten gain. Though I have been blessed by the gods, those I defeat are not all wealthy. At the time, the old merchant’s noodle shop was on the verge of closing for lack of capital. Ayu consulted with him and offered all his winnings to replenish the shop’s funds, working there as a hired hand. The old man was delighted and chose an auspicious day to reopen. When the shop reopened, customers flocked to it like ducks to water, and profits multiplied several times over. Within a few years, the shop’s capital grew to several thousand, and business thrived. Ayu, in turn, served the old man as a father and remained devoted to him for the rest of his life. Later, his wife bore two sons in succession, and Ayu lived to the age of seventy before passing away. His descendants still run the noodle shop as before, and the family enjoys modest prosperity.

Ayu never knew his own surname and took Jia as his own after relying on the old merchant. **9. The Thief’s Reward**

In dead of night, he stole by the hidden beam,
Then chanced upon a rapist fierce as wolf or tiger.
Had the woman refused, two lives would have been lost—
He wrested the blade and struck the black-hearted rogue.

Thrice he cried, *"I’m a thief!"*—yet his spirit was ever bold.
The bundle returned, the debt repaid, gain and loss as fleeting as Chu’s lost bow.

At first, a beggar, then a thief, a certain Jia later amassed great wealth. His descendants entered the official register, and he was honored as a venerable patriarch.

When he was still a thief, there lived in the same town a family surnamed Mou, long prosperous, where three generations of widows had dwelt. Three sisters-in-law—all childless, their husbands dead—faced the extinction of their line. Only the youngest sister-in-law carried a posthumous child, and all hoped for a son to continue the ancestral rites.

On the Clear and Bright Festival, they went to sweep the graves in the countryside. The two elder sisters-in-law made the journey, which would take three days for the round trip. The youngest, being with child, stayed behind, attended by an old serving woman.

Jia, having scouted the house, seized the opportunity to burgle it. At dusk, he scaled the wall and entered, only to see the youngest sister-in-law and the old woman carrying a lamp to check the doors. He slipped into the woman’s chamber and hid.

The woman sat beneath the lamp, reading, while the old woman, feigning drunkenness, urged her to sleep. The woman said, *"Go close the door and rest. Do not disturb me."* The old woman left, leaving the door ajar.

Moments later, a young man pushed open the door. Jia, suspecting a fellow thief, was surprised he had not waited for the woman to sleep—and even more so by his fine, well-kept clothes. The woman, seeing the intruder, rose in alarm and tried to call for the old woman, who did not answer. The young man seized her, demanding her favors. She resisted fiercely, crying out, but the old woman paid no heed.

When the woman refused, the young man drew a knife from his boot and threatened, *"Yield, or I’ll bathe my blade in blood!"* The woman rebuked him: *"My family has always been honorable. I will not suffer the stain of a scoundrel’s touch. Kill me if you must—I will never submit!"* He pressed the knife to her throat.

Jia, watching in mounting fury, suddenly sprang out, wrested the knife from the young man’s hand, and struck him down with a blow to the forehead. The woman, taken by surprise, trembled violently, unable to utter a sound.

Jia rushed out, flung open the door, and shouted, *"Catch the thief!"* The neighbors gathered, asking, *"Where is the thief? Who are you?"* Driven by righteous indignation, Jia had forgotten he had come to steal. Only now did he realize, and he laughed: *"I am a thief—but there are those far more despicable than thieves. Why not follow me?"* And he led the crowd into the woman’s chamber.

"X. The Blessings of a Lowly Constable:
Virtue, Not Birth, Determines Fortune

A Constable’s Son Passes the Imperial Examination—
What Became of Magistrate Deng’s Descendants?
Did Their Noble Lineage Bring Them Equal Renown?

The ancestors of a certain Grand Secretary of Wuxing (present-day Huzhou) once served as a constable in the prefectural yamen. Though his post was base, his heart was loyal and kind, ever mindful of aiding others and benefiting all beings. He often told his peers: *'The public court is a fine place to cultivate the Way. If we who serve in the public court do no good, it is like entering a mountain of treasures only to return empty-handed.'* Thus, whenever villagers came to lodge complaints, he would mediate and urge reconciliation. For the poor whose cause was just, he would especially shield them with all his might. Each night, he would place his rod in the chamber pot, for urine could dispel stasis and promote regeneration. Even when the rod drew blood and flesh lay in disarray, it would not fester. At the time, a certain Magistrate Deng was known for his severity—he would not cease flogging until blood flowed. Yet by this constable’s practice, many lives were preserved. His peers, moved by his example, likewise curbed their greed and cruelty."

At the time, the scholar had excelled in both the annual and triennial examinations, repeatedly topping his cohort—so swiftly claiming first place that he felt certain of securing the *bazhen* selection. Carrying ample funds, he passed his days in the lodging house, reveling in poetry and wine with his fellow scholars, thoroughly content.

At the inn there was a skilled physiognomist who sat behind a curtain at the door, his readings often proving uncannily accurate. The scholar, sharing the same lodgings, grew quite familiar with him. One day, returning with a fish, he teased the physiognomist: “You claim to read fortunes—tell me, will I be able to eat this fish?” The physiognomist glanced at the fish, then at the scholar, and replied, “No.” The scholar went inside, hastily cooked the fish, and set it on the table. He then invited the physiognomist to join him, intending to mock his error. As they were about to sit down, he asked again, “Will I eat it now?” The physiognomist answered, “No.” Before the words had fully left his mouth, a massive serpent dropped from the beam, crushing the pot. The vessel shattered, and the crowd erupted in alarm. The serpent slithered away, tail dragging, and the fish remained uneaten.

Astonished by the man’s uncanny skill, the scholar pressed him. The physiognomist demurred: “What skill? You were only jesting with me, so I jested in return. Had it not been in play, what concern would a mere fish be to fortune-telling?” The scholar then asked whether he would indeed be selected for the *bazhen*. The physiognomist hesitated, saying, “I have long wished to speak frankly, but feared reproach and dared not.” The scholar urged, “What harm could it do?” Finally, the man replied, “You have no hope of selection. Your countenance already bears the shadow of misfortune—three days hence, at the third watch, you will die an unnatural death. Your home is not far; you should return at once to die in your own bed.” The scholar asked, “Can this be avoided?”

Pushing open the door, he saw a woman clutching two children, weeping with bitter sorrow. When he asked her reason, she explained that her husband, having borrowed fifty taels of silver from a powerful family, had been sued by them and thrown into prison. **13. Liu Huiyuan**

*Diligence deserved reward, debts of duty repaid—*
*Clear rewards and punishments command Heaven’s awe.*
*One flaw could not obscure his great virtue,*
*How could a drowned ghost be made a city god?*

Liu Huiyuan, styled Youqing, served as magistrate of Yushan in Jiangyou. Upright, discerning, and diligent, he left no cases unresolved. Unless a litigant was clearly guilty, he did not lightly detain them for trial.

At the time, a tailor named So-and-so was to serve as a witness in a certain case. As the hearing was about to convene, Magistrate Liu departed for the prefectural seat on urgent business. The constables detained both parties to the suit, along with the witnesses, at an inn to await his return.

The tailor’s wife, learning her husband had been taken into custody, grew fearful. She thought, *The magistrate does not lightly detain people—if he has done so, the offense must be grave.* In haste, she took her young son into the city to see him. A sudden flood swept them away, and both drowned.

When Magistrate Liu returned and concluded the case, the tailor returned home to find his family gone—and so he hanged himself. The magistrate remained unaware.

A month later, he again traveled to the provincial capital.

In Wuxing, there was a man named Shen Hongfei, one of three brothers. Hongfei, the second-born, was treacherous by nature. His eldest brother traveled for trade, leaving his wife alone at home. As the youngest brother was still a child, no suspicion arose. Whenever she sent letters to her husband, she would call the youngest to her room to write them, sometimes rewarding him with wine and food for his trouble.

Hongfei had long harbored a slight grudge against his brother and sister-in-law. He falsely accused her of adultery with the youngest brother. He spread the slander to all he met, and soon the vile rumors spread far and wide. Even frivolous men composed *zhu-zhi* verses about it. With no way to clear her name, the sister-in-law ultimately hanged herself.

**15. The Legalist’s Folly**
*He refused again and again to shield his own person—*
*How could he then chase favor as a guest in the yamen?*
*Three days after her hanging, her ghost came to claim his life—*
*Truly a pitiable man, this scholar.*

A scholar from Zhejiang, versed in the techniques of Shen Buhai and Han Fei, traveled to Jiangyou to serve as a legal advisor under a prefect. Once in the yamen, he and his superior got along exceedingly well. The prefect, a formidable official, insisted on personally interrogating all legal cases from the subordinate counties. At the time, a widow surnamed Mou was being harassed by a ruffian. Though she repeatedly rebuffed him, he persisted until, unable to endure the humiliation, she filed a complaint with the county. The ruffian, however, counter-accused her of consensual adultery. The county magistrate, unable to resolve the case, forwarded it to the prefectural court. The prefect, discerning the widow’s innocence, severely punished the ruffian, thus closing the case.

During the trial, the scholar stood behind the screen, gazing at the widow’s beauty with desire. He resolved to take her as his concubine. The widow firmly refused, but he forced the betrothal gifts upon her. Fearing she could not resist the yamen’s power and dreading violation, she hanged herself. Three days after her death, the scholar rose at dawn to find his door still barred. Breaking it open, they discovered him lying on the ground, a knife in hand, his throat slit and blood pooling around him.

Yao Kangming was a younger clansman of my maternal great-uncle. Learned and richly endowed with talent, he had no other grave faults in life, save that his speech was often frivolous and he delighted in using his brush to mock and satirize others. Whenever matters touched upon the inner chambers of others—even if only by suspicion—he would invariably contrive clever connections to shape them into songs and verses. His diction was fresh and refined, and his works were often widely circulated. Yet after repeatedly failing the examinations, and further shunned for his frivolity, no one dared engage him to tutor their children. He eventually died in poverty and starvation, with neither clothes nor bedding at the time of his death, lying in tattered rags teeming with lice. My maternal great-uncle’s family arranged his burial. He left behind a son, who had nowhere to go and was raised by my great-uncle. The boy was rather honest and cautious, giving hope that he might establish himself. Just as plans were made to arrange his marriage, he suddenly died, and the line was thus extinguished. Could this not be the retribution for frivolity?

**17. Elder Hu of the Seal**
*The ringleader’s crime is grave, the coerced’s light—*
*Yet good men bear the name of corrupt clerks.*
*Seven words from the governor moved his heart—*
*"Within the public gate, one may cultivate the Way."*

Elder Hu, father of Prefect Hu Xiangshan, was a clerk in the criminal bureau of Jinshan. He was always loyal and honest, and throughout his life, he disdained to engage in the practice of "raising or lowering his hand" to manipulate cases. When a robbery case occurred in Jinshan, the victim was injured and later died. Over thirty principal and accessory offenders were arrested. At the time, the law was severe: any robber who injured a person, regardless of whether they were the ringleader or an accomplice, was to be executed. As it happened, Elder Hu was assigned to handle this case. Seeing that the thirty-odd men were all impoverished commoners with no livelihood, he could not bear the thought of them being executed side by side. Thus, he drafted a verdict in which only the two who had initiated the robbery and struck the fatal blow were sentenced to death, while the rest were sentenced to military exile. The magistrate suspected the ruling was too lenient, but Elder Hu insisted, "Though this was a robbery, their confessions show they were not habitual criminals. Even the injury to the victim occurred at night, in a sudden scuffle—no blades or weapons were involved. It seems permissible to apply a lighter sentence."

The magistrate, fearing harsh reprimand, said, "If this is questioned, I will be held accountable." Elder Hu replied, "If it is questioned, allow me to go to the provincial capital to answer for the error of leniency." The magistrate, composing himself, said, "If you are still willing to plead for the people’s lives, how could I alone lack a humane heart?" He then submitted the verdict as drafted. As expected, it was rejected, and a new ruling was demanded. Elder Hu again drafted a memorial to uphold the original decision. After three rejections and three resubmissions, the governor became furious, issuing stern reprimands and ordering the case to be brought before him for personal review. He further commanded the magistrate to bring the official seal to Suzhou, clearly intending to impeach him. Terrified, the magistrate blamed Elder Hu. Elder Hu volunteered to accompany him to the provincial capital, saying, "If you meet with the governor, please leave everything to me. If we succeed, it will be your good fortune. If not, I alone will bear the responsibility."

The magistrate thus brought Elder Hu with him to the capital. Upon their audience with the governor, Elder Hu waited outside the yamen gate. The governor rebuked the magistrate for his leniency, his words and tone severe. The magistrate kowtowed and admitted his fault. The governor then asked, "You are newly appointed—who taught you to do this?" The magistrate replied, "The clerk Hu from the criminal bureau." The governor asked, "Did he come with you?"

18. Prefect Zhang: *Transforming a Worthless Life*

A life of vice and ruin—
Yet evil thoughts dissolved in an instant, giving rise to a good heart.
Sitting in the snow, silver in hand, awaiting the owner’s return;
Past transgressions pardoned, he was granted rank and honor.

Prefect Zhang was a native of Jingkou. In his youth as a scholar, he was poor and of ill repute, so that people feared him like a tiger. Yet his nature was rather bold and unrestrained; whatever wealth he extorted or seized, he scattered with his own hands. Many impoverished households in his village relied on his aid, and thus his home had no surplus grain. One New Year’s Eve, he could not even light a fire for cooking.

He reflected that his relatives and acquaintances all harbored old grudges, and most were petty, narrow-minded men—none to whom he could turn.

Yet he could not bear to grovel in supplication. With no recourse as dusk fell, he took his wife’s tattered cloth skirt, pawned it at a broker’s for a thousand coins, and bought a peck of rice, wine, meat, and spirit-money. He placed them in a basket and carried them home. His house stood in a narrow alley; the rain had made the path slick. As he neared home, he tripped and fell, spilling everything from the basket. Enraged, he returned with a lamp to inspect the scene and found a bag—heavy in his grasp. Taking it inside, he saw two silver ingots, dozens of taels of silver fragments, over a hundred foreign coins, several hundred copper coins, an account book, and several promissory notes. He realized it belonged to a silk shop. Overjoyed, he thought this windfall would bring modest prosperity. As he prepared to take it inside, he suddenly reflected that it must have been left by a shop clerk collecting debts—without it, the man would be ruined. Better to wait for the owner to return and seek it. So he hid the bag, used some of the loose change to buy rice, and instructed his wife to cook. He then took up a candle and sat outside his door in the wind and snow.

Before long, he saw an old man and two youths carrying a silk shop lantern, searching the path with frantic urgency. Observing them, he knew they were the ones who had lost the bag. As they drew near, he called out, “What are you looking for?” The old man recognized Zhang and, knowing his disreputable ways, dared not speak plainly, stammering and trying to slip away. Zhang’s expression darkened: “You’re wandering about with a lantern, not searching for what you lost—are you casing houses to rob at night? If you don’t tell me the truth, I won’t let you leave!” The old man had no choice but to confess: “I was collecting debts and passed this way. I rested briefly by the roadside, then hurried on in the rain and lost a cloth bag. I’ve come to look for it, but it’s gone—I suppose some passerby picked it up.” Zhang asked what was inside, and the old man listed the silver, coins, and account books in exact detail. Zhang smiled: “Then come sit in my humble home for a moment. I know who found your things.” The old man bowed and said, “If you know, sir, please tell me at once. I wouldn’t dare impose on your esteemed residence.” Zhang replied, “This isn’t something to discuss standing here. My home is right nearby—why hesitate to grace me with your presence?” The old man wavered, reluctant to go, but Zhang pulled him inside.

Once seated, the old man repeated, “If you know, sir, please tell me. My gratitude will be eternal.” Zhang murmured assent. He went inside, brought out tea, and asked what the old man did at the shop. “Collecting debts,” came the reply. “What will you do now that you’ve lost this?” The old man’s tears streamed down: “Even selling my family wouldn’t cover it. I’ll have to die.” He pleaded again, “If you know, sir, please tell me. My gratitude will be eternal.” Zhang murmured assent once more. Suspecting he was being mocked, the old man stood to leave. Zhang laughed: “Sit down, don’t be impatient. I don’t know who found your things. But I have some savings—I’ll repay you myself.” He brought out the bag and asked, “Is this enough to cover your loss?” The old man was stunned. Glancing at Zhang warily, he stammered, unable to speak. Zhang reassured him: “Don’t suspect me! If I wanted this money, I’d have already offered sacrifices to the gods and shut my door to drink my fill. Why would I sit alone in the wind and snow, waiting for you to arrive?” He emptied the silver and foreign coins onto the table: “The silver and coins are still here—the copper I used to buy rice.” The old man, overjoyed beyond hope, kowtowed endlessly. Rising, he urged Zhang to take half. Zhang refused sternly. The old man said, “If you won’t take it, I can’t leave.” Zhang smiled: “If you insist on giving me something, lend me two foreign coins so I can eat my fill in the New Year.” Seeing his sincerity, the old man dared not argue further. He gave Zhang two coins, bowed in thanks, and departed.

Zhang used the coins to buy more wine and dried meat, offering them to the gods and heaven. He and his wife drank together, then slept drunk. In his dream, he was bound and taken away. He saw a kingly figure resembling the Star Lord Wen Chang, who rebuked him: “Your many misdeeds leave you no time to reform—you’ll fall into the realm of hungry ghosts!” As he begged for mercy, someone entered with a document. The king’s expression softened at once: “This act of great goodness atones for your past transgressions. Your official register shall be restored, and you will pass the autumn examinations.”

The king further addressed Zhang: “When you return home, you must humble yourself and reform your conduct. Your future prospects cannot be measured.” Zhang awoke, realizing it was the act of returning the silver that had earned him divine protection. At daybreak, he immediately prepared a memorial and burned it before the Celestial Emperor, vowing to follow the ledger of merits and demerits to atone for his past transgressions.

Before long, the old man from before, now dressed in formal attire, came to express his gratitude: “Had it not been for you last night, my entire family—old and young—would have perished. I have informed my master, and he will surely reward you.” Zhang politely declined. From then on, he redoubled his efforts to do good, yet his poverty grew more severe, often going several days without lighting a fire to cook.

In the middle of the eighth lunar month, when scholars were preparing to travel to Jinling for the examinations, Zhang alone had not a single coin to his name. With no means even to feed himself, he had long abandoned any thought of entering the examination hall. Suddenly, he encountered the old man again, who asked: “Why have you still not gone to take the examination?” Zhang explained his poverty. The old man said: “You are a virtuous man—how can you not attend the provincial examination? Return home and wait for me there.” Zhang agreed. Upon arriving home, the old man soon followed, presenting him with twenty taels of silver: “This is my accumulated savings. You should board a boat and depart at once.” Zhang gratefully accepted. After the old man left, he privately thought that using the silver for the examination was uncertain, whereas keeping it for firewood and rice would secure him half a year without fear of cold or hunger. He was reluctant to go but worried about disappointing the old man. As he hesitated, he heard a knock at the door.

Elder Liu, a native of Shanghang, was sincere and steadfast from youth, incapable of uttering a deceitful word. Though poor, he took great delight in aiding those in urgent need. In his twentieth year, he lost both parents and, with no means to support himself, had a relative serving as magistrate in eastern Guangdong. He resolved to seek refuge with him. Selling his house, he obtained several tens of taels of silver and set out. Upon reaching Jiangxi, he encountered a fellow townsman, who, fallen on hard times and unable to return home, was about to sell his son into servitude. Moved by compassion, Elder Liu divided half his funds and gave them to him.

When Elder Liu arrived in Guangdong, his relative had already passed away, and his wife and children were transporting the coffin home. With no place to stay, he lodged at an inn, finding himself in dire straits. He soon fell ill, and the innkeeper, pitying this young and solitary traveler, arranged for a physician to treat him. Though his illness abated, his purse was now empty, leaving him unable to return home or repay the innkeeper.

The old man exclaimed in surprise, "Your four ships’ cargo is of immense value—even if I liquidated my entire estate, it would not cover a tenth of it. If there should be any loss, how could I ever repay you?" The foreign merchants replied, "Simply take the goods. Come three years later to collect the payment—how would that be?" Though the old man possessed considerable wealth at the time, he had yet to establish a household. Hearing the three-year term, he frowned and said, "I have no family here. Though I would not, in good conscience, betray another’s trust, the uncertainties of life are beyond prediction. Should some unforeseen misfortune arise within these three years, where would the two of you seek recompense?" Seeing that he could not be persuaded, the merchants turned to their former lodging-house keeper, who managed the old man’s accounts and was trusted by the foreigners, urging him to mediate. After appraising the goods, they valued them at over a million taels, of which only a hundred thousand were paid upfront, the remainder due in three years. A contract was drawn, and the transaction was concluded.

Within two months, war broke out in the West, and no foreign ships arrived, causing the price of imported goods to soar. The old man sold his stock, turning a threefold profit. He consulted with the lodging-house keeper to set aside the principal, using the rest for further trade. His wealth grew daily, and the great families of Guangdong vied to marry into his household. He took a wife, acquired property, and lived in a manner rivaling princes and marquises. Yet he remained ever more sincere, cautious, and generous, bestowing his bounty widely so that many benefited from his kindness.

Five years later, the foreign merchants finally returned. Overjoyed at their arrival, the old man prepared a lavish feast with music and performances, inviting all who had signed the contract and seating the merchants in the place of honor. After several rounds of wine, he raised his cup and declared, "Thanks to the goods from the two of you, I now possess millions. Without your generosity, I could never have attained this. My sales ledgers and trading records from these years are all here. Beyond the original capital, I ask that we divide the profits." The merchants laughed and said, "We had an agreement from the start—profit or loss rests with your fortune and fate, what concern is it of ours? Return our principal, and keep the rest for yourself; do not decline!" The old man insisted otherwise, and they exchanged deferential refusals. The mediator then said to the merchants, "Since Master Liu is so gracious, why not accept interest at one percent per annum on the original sum? It would be only right, and would not disappoint his goodwill." The merchants still demurred.

After several days of deliberation, they ultimately followed the mediator’s suggestion, fully repaying both principal and interest. At once, the foreign merchants all praised Old Man Liu for his sincerity and generosity.

Before long, the Guan trading house collapsed due to insolvency and was sued by the foreign merchants. The authorities sealed its premises and sought a successor to take over, but none could be found. The foreign merchants unanimously recommended Old Man Liu, though he declined, saying, “A foreign trading house requires vast capital—my funds are scattered, how could I reopen it?” The merchants replied, “No matter! Simply register your name with the officials, and we will provide the capital.” Reluctantly, he agreed.

After Old Man Liu took over the house, the foreign merchants flocked to him. In less than a decade, he became the wealthiest man in the province. He lived to over ninety, witnessing the birth of his great-grandchildren. Even now, his family remains one of great prominence.

The Master of Sitting Among Flowers remarked: “As the world’s customs decline daily, cunning deceit grows while honesty wanes. In dealings with others, not a single word comes from the heart—schemes and treachery shift in an instant, a thousandfold. Even ministers deceive their lords, children deceive their fathers, wives deceive their husbands, until the world becomes a realm of artifice. Those who practice such things believe themselves clever, unaware that they provoke Heaven’s wrath! Yet when one or two men of perfect sincerity appear, spirits and gods secretly aid them, smoothing perilous paths as if level ground, until they ultimately enjoy blessings unmatched in the human world. Men like Old Man Liu are truly worthy of emulation!”
