chunks.translated_text:
**20. Washing the Inkstone in the Lotus Pond**

The intimacy with a maidservant by the lotus pond was already detestable—
how much worse to stubbornly deny it before one’s mother-in-law!
Too little time had passed for repentance, and the old ways returned;
in sickness, the demand for her life was entirely justified.

There was a certain scholar from Hangzhou in Zhejiang, a *zhusheng*. He studied the techniques of Shen Buhai and Han Fei under Jiang Yiting, possessing minor talent but given to wild and unrestrained behavior. In the year *bingwu*, Master Jiang took up a post in the yamen of Prefect Xianyun Ya in Shanghai. After the autumn examinations, the scholar visited his teacher at the circuit office and proudly displayed his examination essays to his peers.

At that time, a spirit-writing session was being held in the yamen, and the planchette descended, identifying itself as Master Xia Wanru. The scholar inquired about his official prospects, and the spirit wrote in large characters: *“Your future holds great promise, but alas, your sins of speech and lust have exhausted all merit! Reform swiftly, and you may yet prolong your years. Otherwise, vengeful spirits will soon arrive—do you still hope for scholarly success?”*

The scholar laughed and said, *“Does a celestial being now speak like some pedantic old scholar? If you speak of vengeful spirits, pray tell—what is the cause?”* The planchette wrote again: *“Do you truly wish for plain words? Do you recall the matter of washing your inkstone in the lotus pond ten years ago?”* The scholar’s countenance changed at once, and he kowtowed in silent prayer.

The planchette wrote once more: *“The Underworld has reported to the Osmanthus Palace to strike your name from the rolls and reduce your allotted years—thus do I know of it. If from this moment you earnestly repent your past wrongs, you may yet salvage a fraction of your fate. Mere prayers will be of no avail!”*

**21. Bao Xunquan: A Life Spared, a Verdict Reversed—How Could Host and Guest Share the Same Dream?**

The example of Heaven’s selection of talent shows that scholarly pursuits need not be pursued with such bitter toil.

My kinsman by marriage, Uncle Bao Xunquan, was in his youth enrolled among the scholars but later abandoned his studies. Mastering the techniques of Shen Buhai and Han Fei, he wandered Jiangxi for over a decade. Though the second month brought apricot blossoms and the eighth osmanthus—signs of the metropolitan and provincial examinations—he had long since cast them beyond consideration.

In the *xinhai* year of Daoguang’s reign, he served as a guest administrator in the Gan County yamen. There, several thieves had already been sentenced to death by the previous magistrate. After reviewing their case, Bao grew suspicious and urged the magistrate to re-examine the matter. It was revealed that they were innocent commoners, framed by the constables. Though he sought to pardon them, the military officers schemed for their release, and the magistrate’s orders were obstructed, nearly swayed by their machinations. Bao, however, argued forcefully on principle and ultimately secured their exoneration.

The following year, in the early days of the *wuzǐ* year, he suddenly dreamed of gazing upon a celestial roster bearing his name. Dismissing it as a springtime fancy, he thought no more of it. Two months later, he dreamed again of the same roster, and this time, someone beside him said, *“The heavenly list is fixed—you must return at once.”* He awoke and again paid it no mind. The very next day, the magistrate arrived to urge him to sit for the examinations.

**23. The Robber of Xuancheng**

Where could the jade flee—his schemes so deftly laid?
Wealth and fame both won, his calculations made.
Who could foresee the debt would come knocking at the door,
A bandit’s vengeance clasped tight to his core?

In Xuancheng, a notorious robber had long plundered with impunity, his gold vast and his gang numerous; none in the garrison dared challenge him. A certain prefect, stern and capable, upon assuming office for less than ten days, devised a plan to capture him. The robber offered a massive bribe, which the prefect discussed with his confidant. The confidant urged him not to accept, but the prefect smiled and said, "If I kill him, where could the jade go?" He took the bribe yet still executed the robber as planned. On the night the robber was put to death, the prefect’s gatekeeper saw the robber enter the residence, unchecked by shouts; though pursued, he vanished into the inner chambers. At dawn, the prefect’s concubine bore a son. When the boy grew up, he ruined the family’s fortune—all knew he had come to collect the robber’s debt.

**24. The Ghost Seizes the Remarried Woman**

Her husband’s murder—how lamentable the deed,
With stolen wealth, she fled to strum the pipa’s lead.

**25. Silver Hidden in a Plum Tree**

A humble hut transformed in an instant to vermilion gates—
Yet rare is the tailor’s ancient virtue, steadfast and true.
Inscribed upon this painting, the cry of dismay resounds:
Who could have foreseen that a lowly script would mirror Wen Sun’s hand?

Han Shushan of Yunjian, ¹ a man of wealth who cherished propriety, acted without hesitation when righteousness demanded, earning the esteem of his village as a man of virtue. The tale of how he amassed his fortune offers a lesson worth heeding.

Shushan’s ancestors were poor. His father, Old Man Han, worked as a tailor, setting up shop west of Xiuye Bridge. Though his craft was humble, his kindness knew no bounds. One year, as the year’s end approached, a heavy snowfall blanketed the earth. ² At midnight, having finished his work, he was about to retire when suddenly the door knocker rattled violently, as if someone leaned against it. A sigh was heard. Holding up a candle, he opened the door to find a man seated there, clutching a bundle. Upon inquiry, he learned the stranger was a clerk from a Shanghai firm, returning from collecting debts in Zhapu. The hour was late, and he had missed both the last boat and any available lodging, intending to spend the night under the eaves until dawn.

Old Man Han exclaimed in alarm, "Since you’ve just collected debts, your purse cannot be empty—how can you sleep exposed to the elements? Even if nothing befalls you, how will you endure such bitter cold? Though my home is cramped and lowly, it can at least shield you from wind and snow." With that, he invited the man inside.

**26. Uprightness as Divinity**
*A spotless official becomes a spirit—his governance unerring,*
*Sweet melons and hemp flourish where he treads.*
*He scoffs at the Daoist’s idle ease,*
*Yet in dreams, he startles awake to meet Magistrate Xu.*

Xu Yunián was my maternal grandaunt’s brother. A man of vast learning, skilled in poetry and painting, his nature was forthright and unguarded, rushing to aid others in distress as if he could never do enough. He cherished talent above all, and upon witnessing even a single virtue in a person, he would praise them without cease.

Having passed the provincial examination in the *xinsi* year of the Daoguang era, he was appointed magistrate of Huan County in Gansu, later transferred to Dunhuang and promoted to prefect of Anxi. All the places he governed lay at the farthest frontiers. Their people were honest and simple, free from the cunning and litigious habits of the interior. Master Xu governed them with quiet dignity. Lawsuits were judged and settled the same day, with no cases left unresolved. He maintained the strictest personal integrity, and in his spare time, he would summon the most promising scholars to instruct them in composition and refine their literary skills.

Observing the abundance of mulberry trees in the region, he specially hired silkworm-rearing women from his hometown to teach the locals the methods of raising silkworms and reeling silk. Wherever he went, voices of praise arose, and when he departed, the people enshrined and worshipped him as a deity.

He had barely reached fifty when he died of illness in the official residence of Anxi. Earlier, during his tenure as magistrate of Dunhuang, there was a Daoist in the City God Temple who frequently broke the law. Master Xu expelled him from the county. After Xu left office, the Daoist, through underhanded connections, regained his position as temple abbot and resumed his misconduct as before.

One morning, the Daoist awoke, suddenly rolled up his belongings, and attempted to flee in a state of great panic.

**27. Two Cases of Disaster Assessment**

*Diligence and caution still fail to ensure real relief—*
*How much worse when tasks are left to clerks and underlings?*
*Both lives cut short, yet spare no pity—*
*The official’s warrant was no summons of death.*

County Assistant Magistrate So-and-so awaited his post in Jiangsu. Assigned to act as Assistant Magistrate of Fengxian County, he was placed in charge of the Fourth Tuan Township. At the time, the previous official had died of illness, and his coffin still remained in the yamen. The assistant magistrate, bringing his family, temporarily lodged in the City God’s Temple.

That year, the county suffered flooding, and both tax exemptions and disaster relief were implemented. The prefectural government issued an order for him to survey the disaster-stricken households in his township. Coincidentally, the Provincial Administration Commissioner had also sent an official to the area. The two men, being old acquaintances, soon arranged to live together. Day after day, they indulged in drinking and singing, entrusting the task entirely to clerks, village heads, and local constables. These underlings colluded in fraud, engaging in embezzlement and false claims, so that the impoverished people received no real benefit.

Before long, the assistant magistrate and his wife died suddenly without illness, one after the other. The commissioner’s delegate returned to the provincial capital to report on his mission and died within a month. The assistant magistrate was not yet forty, the age of vigorous service, and had no serious faults—yet he met such a grim retribution. People suspected that his family’s residence in the temple had profaned the deity, provoking divine wrath. But observing the cause of his death, one sees that the netherworld’s punishment lay here, not there!

Again, in the *gengyin* year of the Daoguang reign (1830), the region north of the Yangtze suffered a great famine.

The Yu family of Jiaxing was a great household of the prefecture, owning many properties. A certain Zhu, who made his living selling fish, rented one of their houses to live in. The house stood beside the prefectural yamen, part of the dowry of Madam Yu the Elder. Each year’s end, the old lady would send an elderly woman or a maidservant to collect the rent—not entrusting the task to servants or stewards, so there was no harassment or clamor. Zhu found this convenient and lived in peace, and so it had been for years.

Though Zhu was but a small peddler, his nature was generous and open-hearted, ever ready to aid those in distress. Once in the marketplace, he came upon a man and woman with a child of about ten, weeping together so piteously that passersby were moved. Zhu asked what was wrong, and they replied that they were from Huai’an. Their home had been ruined in a flood, and they had drifted here. Hearing that this year’s harvest was abundant, they wished to return but lacked the means. They had considered selling the wife, but her resolve could not be shaken; selling the child, yet their hearts could not bear parting. At a loss, with hunger gnawing at them, they could only cling to one another and weep. Zhu asked how much they needed to bring wife and child home. “Just two thousand coins would suffice,” they said. Zhu immediately took them home and gave them the full amount. People all mocked him, but such acts of kindness were common for him.

The maidservant laughed and said, “I have already come twice! The first time was just when you, good sir and madam, were ‘unearthing the treasure’—I dared not disturb you. When I returned and told the Lady, she remarked that at seventy years of age, she had seen gold, jewels, and jade in great abundance, yet never a buried silver ingot. She wished to beg one to refresh her eyes and ears. That is why I have come again, and I shall return it promptly—pray do not begrudge it.”

Zhu smiled and said, “This is but a rustic New Year’s custom, not a true discovery of buried treasure. Where would we find silver to present to the Lady?”

The maidservant’s face darkened with anger. “How truly petty and mean! Would the Lady deceive you over a single silver ingot? You make excuses to refuse me!”

Zhu and his wife vehemently denied having any silver, but the maidservant grew furious. “This house belongs to the Lady, and the buried silver came from it—how dare you claim it as your own? I shall report this to the Lady, and she will send her steward to question you!” With that, she brushed her sleeves and strode off.

Zhu and his wife stared at each other in astonishment. After a short while, the maidservant returned with a message, carrying two silver ingots. She offered them to Zhu, saying, “The Lady knows that those who unearth buried treasure must not use it hastily, for hasty use leads to swift depletion. She now offers two ingots in exchange for one, as an omen that your future business ventures will yield double the profit. Pray do not refuse again.”

Zhu was about to speak further, but his wife signaled him with her eyes and said to the maidservant, “Since the Lady has so graciously instructed us, how dare we continue to conceal it? But first, please drink a cup of wine, and we shall fetch it for you.” She then beckoned her husband outside and handed him a silver ingot, saying, “Quickly melt some sealing wax and mix it with mud to coat it.”

**31. Seven Cases of Reaping Retribution for Capturing Bandits**

To be a notorious bandit is to deserve the blade;
To scheme beyond one’s bounds is to forfeit life.
A warning to all ambitious men of rank:
Beware the day you cross paths with Nine-Catty Wang.

Many who capture bandits rise in office,
Yet wrongs go unredressed, grievances unheard.
Who could have known that, once his triumph faded,
His son would lose his wits, his line be severed?

Father and son, eager to display their prowess, seized a mighty brigand,
Greed for merit led them to record the bandit’s name.
Who could have foreseen the brave constable would vanish into a fish’s belly?
The verdict sealed, they met a sudden, violent end.

Magistrate’s Clerk Zhao Wen, a man of Li County, was bold and capable but restless and impatient. Considering his post a dead end with no path to promotion, he believed that capturing bandits from neighboring jurisdictions was his surest route to advancement. He spared no expense, hiring informants and pursuing fugitives, netting several arrests—though none were ringleaders.

Now, there was a certain Nine-Catty Wang, a notorious bandit of Zhejiang Province. When Li learned of his whereabouts, he secretly reported to his superiors, obtained a warrant, and crossed into another jurisdiction to apprehend him. Wang confessed at once upon interrogation and was executed according to the law. Li, having captured a major bandit from a neighboring province, was summoned to the capital for an audience. On his way, he stopped in the provincial capital to await his credentials. While lodging at an inn, a fellow official awaiting appointment approached him for a loan. Li entered his room, opened his trunk to retrieve silver, but found the lock jammed. Pressed by the borrower, he wrenched the lock with such force that the contents inside shifted violently. When the trunk finally sprang open, a knife clattered to the floor. Enraged, Li stamped his foot, his shoe flying off, and stomped barefoot upon the ground, shrieking wildly before collapsing.

At that very moment, Subprefect Wang Juru, who was also awaiting appointment in the provincial capital and was Li’s closest friend, happened to be staying at the same inn.

**33. The Delicate Maiden of Wu Gate**

Resentful yet not wrathful—pity her plight,
Two new poems dashed off in idle strokes.
Beware the ruts of old—do not tread them again,
For Gao of Jiaxing is the cart before you.

In the autumn examination of the *renzi* year, Gao of Jiaxing, after completing the three essays of the first session, suddenly inscribed two quatrains in large script:

*"Do you recall the time we stood beneath the blossoms in the moonlight?
Deep in the night, I secretly composed love poems.
This time, as you take the autumn exam, the cold wind bites—
The frost has seeped through my silk slippers, though you know it not."* (First poem)

*"Beneath the deep yellow earth, jade bones lie sleeping,
A desolate gaze back—all fades like mist.
No need to weave another* Record of Passing the Examinations *(The* New唐书·艺文志 *records:* Cui’s *Record of Passing the Examinations in Xianqing* [era], five juan; Li Yi’s *Record of Passing the Examinations*, two juan),
For when the mandarin ducks are embroidered, one becomes an immortal."* (Second poem)

Afterward, he inscribed *"By the Delicate Maiden of Wu Gate"* (吴门: Suzhou) on the sealed examination hall (锁院: the examination compound) in Zhejiang. Upon leaving the hall, he hired a boat and set off for home by starlight, but died before reaching his household. This must have been a case of seduction and abandonment, leading to death with lingering resentment. Yet the verses are "resentful yet not wrathful" (These four characters derive from the *Analects* commentary on "poems that may express resentment"), capturing well the essence of the *feng* poet (风人: poet). Still, to have given herself to an unworthy man and thus become an ill-fated pair (The *Zuozhuan* states: "An ill-fated pair is called an enemy")—how lamentable!

Mingde feigned hesitation and said, “Has the payment already been made?” “Not yet,” the buyer replied. “If not,” Mingde said, “there may still be a way. 38. The Potent Virtue of the Pan Clan
Wealth cannot buy worthy descendants—
Who has cultivated such pious karma?
Fortunate that the eldest son could carry on the legacy,
Riches and honor should endure in unbroken succession.

The Pan clan of Wu Gate was renowned for its virtue through the generations, and Heaven thus greatly prospered its descendants, gathering and nurturing their brilliance. Among them was the Grand Tutor, Duke Wengong, whose rank reached the highest of the Three Dukes and whose person embodied the Five Blessings. The fullness of his good fortune was unmatched not only in recent times but also rare among the ancients.

The origins of his flourishing fortune have been recorded in many other texts, and there is no need for redundant repetition. The Grand Tutor’s eldest son, Gongfu, a cultivated talent, delighted in goodness and was generous in bestowing alms, yet sought no official advancement. Though the Grand Tutor held power in the court for over a decade, Gongfu would visit the capital only every other year to pay his respects, returning home soon after. While residing at home, he refused private audiences with those in power; if they came to see him, he did not turn them away. He was well-versed in discussing local advantages and grievances, yet never sought personal gain from such matters, nor did he return visits in kind.

**Three-Nine Antidote for Arsenic Poisoning**

The essence of practicing medicine lies in saving lives with a compassionate heart;
Extorting wealth at will is never justified.
Nine lives wronged by your greed shall be repaid by yours—
Nine generations fated to die by arsenic, the judgment is clear.

A man of She County, Jiang Zigang, possessed a secret formula to instantly neutralize arsenic poisoning. Yet those who sought his remedy were forced to pay exorbitant sums; if his demands were not met, he would sit idly by and watch them perish. One day, while traveling to a neighboring county to practice medicine, he died suddenly in the night. He appeared in a dream to his host, saying: *"For my obsession with profit, I caused the deaths of nine people. The deceased brought their grievances before the underworld court, where it was decreed that I must suffer arsenic poisoning for nine lifetimes. Now, I am to enter the cycle of rebirth. I bribed the ghostly attendants to pass on this antidote to you. If you save one life with it, I shall be spared one lifetime of karmic retribution. Should you spread it widely to aid the world, your merit will be boundless."*

With that, he wept and departed, lamenting, *"My remorse comes too late!"* The formula consisted solely of one *liang* of *fangfeng* ground into powder and taken with water—no other ingredients were needed. *Strange Tales Worthy of Belief* also records that arsenic poisoning can be miraculously cured by mixing gypsum with cold water.

From the *Book of Jin: Treatises on Carriages and Attire*: "The outriders and retinue of the *Zouqi* lead the procession." Those who traveled the roads and failed to yield swiftly enough were flogged without mercy. One day, the magistrate was returning from the western outskirts of the city when he encountered a paper merchant carrying his wares on a shoulder pole, standing by the roadside. Enraged that the man had not set down his burden, the magistrate ordered his underlings to drag him before his palanquin and berated him. The man, simple and stubborn, grew indignant and said, "I never blocked the road—what crime is there in not setting down my load?" The magistrate flew into a rage: "What lowly wretch dares defy me so!" He ordered his men to beat the man severely. After the flogging, he had him dragged forward again and demanded, "Do you admit your guilt?" The man replied, "What crime have I committed? I truly do not know!" The magistrate, cruel and obstinate, could not bear to be humiliated by a commoner in the streets. Shame and fury rising, he ordered the man beaten hundreds more times. Blood and flesh flew in all directions, yet still he did not relent. He commanded his men to escort the man to Huating to stand trial for obstructing the road. The clerks and runners extorted tens of thousands of coins from the shopkeeper, but fortunately, the magistrate of Huating, seeing the man’s grievous wounds, did not press further charges. After several days in custody, he was released and sent home. Upon his return, the shopkeeper, resentful of the trouble he had caused, drove him away. The man, already subjected to brutal punishment and now cast out by his employer, hanged himself.

Within ten days, the magistrate’s back erupted in five carbuncles, the pain unbearable. The physicians called this condition "A Hundred Birds Paying Homage to the Phoenix" and said that if the sores did not fester, there might still be hope. One night, he dreamed of the paper merchant lifting his hand to tear at the carbuncles. The agony was so intense that he screamed and awoke, calling for his maidservant to bring a light. The carbuncles had all burst, pus and blood soaking his bedding. Every physician threw up their hands in despair. From then on, whenever he closed his eyes, he saw the paper merchant standing before him. No prayers or exorcisms brought relief. He could no longer lie flat but had to prop himself up, resting his head on the bedframe. The slightest movement sent pain searing through his heart and lungs. Those who saw him said it was a vision of hell itself. He shrieked in torment for weeks before dying. At the moment of his death, the entire yamen saw the figure of the paper merchant in the air.

The Master of the Flower Seat remarked: "When scholar-officials wield power, they often act recklessly, heedless of others’ suffering. Alas! Are not all men of the same kind? How can one indulge such cruelty and call it gratification?"

**42. The Ox-Headed Man**
*Karmic retribution from past lives pursues one in the present;*
*The Mirror of Karma reveals the seeds of disaster.*
*Fortunate to meet a monk midway,*

In the eastern region of Zhe, a scholar named Wang was strolling through the countryside one spring day when he encountered an old cow in the fields. As it lowered its horns to charge, Wang hurried past, but the beast wheeled around, intent on pursuit, only to be restrained by its herder. Even so, it strained against the rope, stamping its hooves and fixing him with a wide-eyed glare.

(Continuing the account:) The term "confronting the record" refers to being called to answer for one’s deeds. Among the plaintiffs—some male, some female—all bore ox-heads upon human bodies, and each accused Scholar Wang of having harmed them. Seated above was an official crowned with coral, his court robes draped with strands of pearls, his attire resembling that of a censor. He demanded of Wang how he had killed so many oxen.

Wang declared that for generations his family had upheld Confucian learning, abstaining from beef and dog meat for three lifetimes—how could he have slain cattle? The presiding judge ordered a green-robed clerk to bring forth a mirror and bid Wang gaze into it. In that moment, he suddenly recalled his past life as a butcher, wielding sharp blades with consummate skill, often slaughtering over ten oxen in a single day. By middle age, he had deeply repented his trade, fearing karmic retribution, and so shaved his head to become a monk on Mount Tiantai. His discipline was rigorous, and at over eighty years of age, he passed away seated in meditation. Yet due to his past sins, he could not ascend to the Trāyastriṃśa Heaven.

Once Wang grasped the cause of his former existence, he bowed his head and confessed.

The presiding judge then addressed him, saying, "Since you have transmigrated from the cycle of rebirth as a śramaṇa, do you still retain knowledge of the inner scriptures in this life?" Wang replied, "At the age of twelve, I copied seven scrolls of the *Vajracchedikā Prajñāpāramitā Sūtra* for my parents to dedicate merit to my grandparents in the afterlife. Turning to the assembly of ox-headed figures, he said, "Wang has already laid down the butcher’s knife and sincerely cultivated the Buddhist fruit. Though his karmic sins of killing were not yet exhausted, causing him to fall back into the cycle of rebirth, I propose that he now perform repentance rites for you all, allowing him to return to the human realm. What say you?" The assembly assented in agreement.

Wang then vowed to adopt a vegetarian diet for forty-nine days with his entire household, commission five hundred copies of the *Vajracchedikā Sūtra*, and dedicate them to pray for the plaintiffs’ rebirth in the Pure Land. The presiding judge explained this to the assembly, and all were moved with gratitude, joyfully agreeing to release their grievances. The judge then ordered a black-robed attendant to escort Wang home.

Upon reaching his door, he awoke and fulfilled his vow, reciting the sūtra as promised. He also had ten scrolls of the sūtra transcribed in gold ink and distributed them to various temples for veneration. After completing these acts, he dreamed once more of the men and women returning to express their thanks: "By the power of your sūtras, we have all escaped the animal realm and been reborn into wealthy and noble families!" **1. Enduring Slander Without Protest**

A man of humble means yet content in poverty,
His pulse-touched heart repays silver to ease a patient’s woe.
With boundless magnanimity, he stores unseen virtue—
Where else could such a noble elder be found?

The late father of Prefect Wei of Changzhou was a man of generosity and benevolence, well-versed in the healing arts of Qi and Huang. Whether treating the rich or the poor, he devoted himself wholeheartedly, never demanding payment. For those too destitute to afford medicine, he would even donate funds to provide remedies. When villagers traveled to the city for treatment, he would first offer them congee or cakes. Only after they had eaten would he take their pulse, explaining: “Long journeys and hunger disrupt the blood and qi. I give you food to rest briefly so that your pulse may settle. Do I do this out of mere kindness? No—I do it to refine my art.”

Such were his pretexts for doing good. Once, he was summoned to treat a patient who had lost ten taels of silver from beside his pillow. The patient’s son, swayed by slander, suspected the elder of theft but dared not confront him. Someone advised him to kneel at the elder’s gate with incense in hand. Seeing this, the elder asked in surprise, “What are you doing?” The young man replied, “I have a matter to ask but fear your reproach, so I dare not speak.” The elder said, “Speak freely; I will not blame you.” When the truth was revealed, the elder led him into a private chamber and said, “The matter is true. I temporarily used the silver for an urgent need and intended to return it discreetly during my next visit, like ‘restoring the jade to Zhao.’ Since you’ve asked, take it now—but tell no one.” He then counted out the silver and gave it to him.

When the son first arrived with incense, people assumed the elder, known for his integrity, would never commit such a base act. But when the silver was returned, they sighed, “How unfathomable the human heart can be!” Slander spread rapidly, yet the elder remained unperturbed, dismissing it with indifference.

Soon after, the patient recovered and, while tidying his bedding, found the lost silver beneath his mattress. Stricken with remorse, he exclaimed, “The silver was here all along—how could I have wronged such a virtuous man? I must go at once to clear his name before the crowd, lest he bear this unjust stain any longer.” Father and son hastened to the elder’s gate, kneeling once more with incense. Seeing them, the elder smiled and asked, “What brings you here now?” The son, shamefaced, replied, “The lost silver was found. I wrongly suspected you, and for that, I deserve death. Here is the silver you returned to me. Punish me as you see fit.” The elder laughed, helped him up, and said, “It was nothing. Pay it no mind.”

The son then asked calmly, “When I slandered you before, why did you endure the defamation without protest, leaving me so deeply ashamed? Now that you’ve forgiven me, may I ask the reason?”

Elder Wei reached the venerable age of eighty, repeatedly receiving imperial patents of nobility. Many of his grandsons also gained official positions. Those with discernment said, “Heaven’s dispensation of reward to the virtuous is never in error!”

**II. The Serpent’s Cry in the Belly**

The viper and serpent take form, crying within the womb—
Drowning daughters has always been a sin most grave.
I wish officials and gentry would heed this plea:
Raise infants, protect the young, and spread their care.

In Huzhou, poor families often practiced the custom of drowning infant girls. My mother once spoke of a relative’s maidservant who, after marriage, gave birth to daughters and drowned each one. Over ten years, she bore seven girls, not one spared. Later, she conceived again, but when the time came for delivery, no child was born—only the sound of a serpent hissing in her belly, heard for a day and a night, until she shrieked and died.

As the *Book of Songs* says: *“The viper and the serpent—these are the omens of women.”* Could it be that the serpent’s cry in her belly was the transformation of the drowned girls’ vengeful resentment?

---

**III. Saving a Life to Extend One’s Own**

A shared boat reveals deep compassion—
One sees the elder was no sinful man.
The underworld’s messenger, punished for leaking secrets,
Laughs at the burden he bore, no light matter.

At year’s end, Elder Wang of Xiuning was returning home after collecting debts, sailing in a small boat through wind and snow. A man on the shore begged to board, but the boatman refused. The elder alone took pity and allowed him. Once aboard, the man was nearly frozen and starved to stiffness. The elder warmed him with a tattered fur coat and gave him fiery liquor. After some time, the man could speak and kowtowed in thanks. When asked about his circumstances, he said, “I am no mortal—I am the City God’s messenger, sent to collect souls!”

Asked whose souls he was to collect, the messenger produced a register listing thirty-three names, with the elder’s at the very top. Terrified, the elder knelt before him and pleaded for mercy.

Four: Jealousy and Villainy Lead to Wrongful Killing

How could a young maiden bear to lose her way at night?
A moment’s misjudgment—her head was severed outright.
For one person’s sake, four lives were cruelly undone;
The character for "knife" within "jealousy" is no false pun.

There were two clerks, Chen and Zhou, born in the same village, living in the same hamlet, both serving as scribes in the Yuzhou Judicial Commission. Whenever their shifts changed and they traveled to and from work, they always agreed to journey together. That year, as they were returning from their shift, Chen delayed for some business and urged Zhou to go ahead, so Zhou set off alone. He rode a mare, reins in hand, proceeding at an unhurried pace. At a fork in the road, he encountered a young woman riding a stallion, clip-clopping toward him. The stallion, seeing the mare, followed her, and the woman did not notice. As dusk fell, the woman asked Zhou, “How much farther to such-and-such a village?” Zhou, surprised, said, “You’ve taken the wrong road! That village lies to the west, yet this place is fifty *li* away. With night falling and no companion, I fear you’ll never reach it!” Hearing Zhou’s words, the woman was startled and began to weep. “What am I to do?” she cried. Zhou said, “I have a small farmstead about two *li* from here. Come with me for now, and stay the night at my tenant’s house. Tomorrow, you can follow the road to your destination—would that be acceptable?” The woman had no choice but to agree. Zhou then said, “You are a young woman, and I am a lone traveler. My tenant might grow suspicious. Why not pretend to be my relative?” The woman reluctantly consented.

Five: A Son’s Death and Rebirth
Nine Demons Left by Ancestral Wickedness—
To Ruin a House, Waste is the Sure Path;
Better to Exhaust Wealth in Alms and Relief—
Five Sons Reborn, Their Blessings Overflow

At Lotus Lake, Duke Wang Wenjian’s forebear, a certain elder, once held wealth that dominated the countryside. After reaching his twentieth year, he fathered nine sons in succession, yet all proved dull and slow-witted. In a certain year of the Qianlong reign, famine struck severely, and many bore the gaunt look of starvation. The elder spent his entire fortune to relieve his fellow villagers, saving countless lives, though his own household thereby declined into reduced circumstances.

Before long, his eldest son fell ill and died. Within a year, all nine sons perished one after another, leaving not a single survivor. The couple grieved in bitterness, their minds dazed as if deranged. Having long venerated the Great Compassionate Bodhisattva Guanyin, they composed a memorial, burning it before her image—its words laden with sorrow and resentment.

**VI. The Palace Examination Scroll Written in Pale Ink**
How perilous—seizing the moment to topple another!
Hard-won imperial words, sharp with rebuke.
Yet pale ink alone sealed the favor of connections,
While master and disciples, brothers in deed, shared equal renown.

When Lord Wenjian Wang and his younger brother Yiwu were students, they had already earned distinction in the academies. The education commissioner, Master Donggao Dou, held them in high regard, and they were known together as the "Two Wangs." After passing the provincial examinations, they sat for the *yǐmǎo* metropolitan examination. Dou, now chief examiner, set the first question on the passage: *"What the people love, the ruler must love."* During his tenure as commissioner, he had visited Huzhou Prefecture to inspect the schools and lecture on the classics, arriving at a unique interpretation of this passage. Now, by coincidence, it became the examination topic. Among all the candidates, only the Two Wangs’ answers aligned with his own understanding. When the results were announced, Yiwu placed first as *huìyuán*, while Wenjian ranked second. Those who failed the examination soon spread groundless rumors.

At the time, Prime Minister Xiang was in power. Disliking Dou’s unyielding integrity and refusal to curry favor, he sought a way to undermine him. Hearing the rumors, he rejoiced and promptly reported them to the emperor.

**X. The Incense Shop**

Cast out by dog, kept by man—
A petty gain sought, wrath from the gods began.
Had the husband heeded not his wife’s plea,
No cause would explain her death and his ruin’s decree.

In Wuxing, a certain couple ran an incense shop. One day, as they dried incense in an open space outside their door, a dog urinated upon it. A neighbor informed the husband, who wished to discard the tainted goods. The wife, however, mindful of their capital, insisted they keep it. Persuaded by her words, the husband mixed the soiled incense with the good and sold it all within days. Before two months had passed, their shop was consumed by fire. It was the height of summer, and the wife was bathing in an upper chamber when the flames took her. After the fire subsided, only a single foot of her remains could be found; the rest had turned to ash. Those who understood such matters deemed it retribution for defiling the sacred.

Wealth amassed through usury seems secure,

Later, Jiang bore a son named Dezhang, who took no interest in the family’s livelihood or estate. Scarcely had he reached twenty when he made gambling and dissipation his sole pursuits. Each time he ventured out, he carried several deeds of his fields as stakes, often wagering a single deed for ten taels of silver. When his silver ran out at the gaming table, he would return the next day to sign the contract—only for his opponent to deceive him, saying, “Did you not borrow fifty taels from me yesterday? How could you forget so soon?” Without protest, Dezhang would draw up a contract for fifty taels and hand it over. Seeing how easily he was duped, others swarmed to cheat him. Within a decade, he squandered his entire inheritance and died.

At Huangyan Bridge in Danyang, there lived a man named Zhou Shengzhang, whose family had modest means. In a certain year of the Qianlong reign, the wheat harvest was abundant, and the price of wheat fell to two hundred *wen* per *shi*. Shengzhang owned a hundred *mu* of land, yielding twice the usual harvest. In Danyang and Jintan counties, people relied on wheat as their staple. That year, Shengzhang encountered several windfalls and hoarded nearly four thousand *shi* of wheat. The following year brought famine; not a grain was reaped in spring or autumn, and both rice and wheat soared in price. Shengzhang kept his granaries sealed, refusing to sell. That winter, the Grand Canal ran shallow, halting merchant traffic, and wheat seed nearly vanished—save for Shengzhang’s hoard. The villagers of the surrounding hamlets came begging for loans. At first, he refused, but after repeated pleas, he agreed to exchange one *shi* of wheat—mixed with chaff and husks—for one *mu* of land. When his wheat was exhausted, the contracts filled his chests, and he had acquired five thousand *mu*. By nature frugal and skilled in accumulation, within a few years his fields exceeded ten thousand *mu*, and his gold and silver piled like mountains. Yet he had no heir. After countless prayers, in his old age he finally fathered a son. Born when he was sixty-eight, the child was named Liu Ba. Before Liu Ba turned ten, Shengzhang died. As he grew older, he treated gold and silver as dirt. Each outing required heavy purses, which he emptied before returning home. If on some days he had nothing to spend, he would fling the coins into the field ridges.

At the time, the community granary system was in effect, and the wealthiest man in each village was appointed as its steward. Liu Ba was thus entrusted with the role. The villagers, taking advantage of his youth and folly, borrowed grain from the granary, then colluded to default on repayment each autumn, leaving him to cover endless losses. Fond of gambling, he would wager a thousand taels in a single throw. As his family’s fortunes dwindled, he sold off his estates—so hastily that contracts were not even drafted, and deeds were carved onto wooden blocks for sale. By the time he died, he had not a single rafter of a house or a *mu* of land to his name.

When my father served as magistrate’s clerk in Danyang, Liu Ba’s son had no means of survival and was reduced to serving as a gatekeeper to eke out a living. To this day, when the villagers speak of prodigal sons, they curse them as “Liu Ba.”

Having thus overzealously pursued the suppression of illicit salt, his former henchmen—once his claws and fangs—all turned into bitter enemies. They gathered in force and tore down his house. The fruits of years of extortion vanished in an instant, leaving only a heap of rubble.

Alas! What profit was there in it?

XII. White Cloud Hermitage

In drunken revelry, he stumbled before the god,
Foolishly seeking an auspicious lot for imperial exams.
Cursing the deity, he provoked divine wrath—
Through all three sessions, he toiled like a silkworm in spring.

By the lake in my Hangzhou stands White Cloud Hermitage, where the Old Man Under the Moon is enshrined. Its oracle slips draw from classics, histories, and even fine lines of poetry and song. For those seeking success in examinations or marriage, its responses are as swift as an echo. Thus, during the provincial examinations, scholars flocked to pray for divination slips.

A certain Qian, a student of the imperial academy, was arrogant in his talent and unrestrained in conduct. Before the *xinmao* examinations, he toured the lake with friends. After heavy drinking, emboldened by wine, he visited the Old Man’s shrine to draw a slip—only to receive an unfavorable response. He laughed, “How could I not pass?” and drew again, only to receive the same. Enraged, he cried, “Your answers are irrelevant! How can you claim to be efficacious?” He then hurled vulgar insults at the shrine. Finally, he declared, “I’ll draw one more. If it still doesn’t suit me, I’ll smash your statue!” The slip he drew read:

*Enough, enough, enough—
Like a spring silkworm spinning its cocoon,
Till death, it draws out its thread.*

His companions, aghast, knew he had provoked divine wrath and urged him to leave. That autumn, during the third session of the examinations, Qian entered the latrine. Suddenly, as if seized by something, he shrieked and staggered out. Returning to his cell, he sat in silence. When the proctor heard no sound, he lifted the curtain—only to find Qian dead. Though the cause remains unknown, his audacity in insulting the deity revealed his lifelong recklessness. The Old Man Under the Moon’s numinous power is truly fearsome!

---

XIII. Madame Yan

She dared to open the granary to relieve famine,
Relying on all to distribute aid justly.
When guilt came, she bore it alone—
Willing to ruin her estate to replenish the public store.

Governor Yan Jingfu, upon first assuming office as magistrate of Pingdu Prefecture in Shandong, was upright, enlightened, compassionate, and benevolent—possessing the virtues of an ancient model official. His mother, Madame Yan, resided with him in the yamen, constantly instructing her son in benevolence and kindness.

In the fifth month of a certain year during the Qianlong reign, the governor traveled to the provincial capital on official business. Suddenly, a great flood struck the prefecture, sweeping away countless homes. Tens of thousands of villagers fled into the city, but the waters continued to rise until only three planks of the city walls remained above the surface. With no food to be had, the refugees’ wails shook heaven and earth. The officials stood helpless, at a loss for what to do.

**Fourteen. Following Precedent in Two Cases**
*An official kept his hands clean and never took bribes—*
*Why then was his line cut off after his death?*
*He submitted a memorial to the City God to inquire about karmic retribution,*
*Only to be told that following precedent was no excuse.*

Fei Gong of Gui’an began his career as a county magistrate and rose to the rank of judicial commissioner. By nature, he was incorruptible and refused private petitions. Once entrusted with the authority of the judiciary, he upheld the law in every case without bending the rules. In his old age, he remained childless. After retiring from office, he reflected on his decades of service and wondered: if he had maintained such unblemished integrity, why had he been repaid with the punishment of a sonless lineage? He then submitted a formal memorial to the City God’s temple to plead his case.

That night, he dreamed that an underling from the City God’s temple summoned him. Upon arrival, he saw the deity descend the steps to welcome him inside. Once seated, the god addressed him: “I read your memorial and sensed your indignation, so I specially invited you here to settle the matter. Your refusal to take bribes or show favoritism is a heart that could face Heaven itself. Yet you wielded judicial power for years—what did you rely upon to honor your lord and protect the people?”

Fei replied, “Nothing more than handling every matter according to precedent.”

The god smiled and said, “Your lack of descendants is precisely because of these three words: *following precedent*.”

Startled, Fei asked, “Then should precedent not be followed?”

The god replied, “That is not what I meant.”

Fei, a scholar, have you not heard that *laws establish great statutes, while rites accord with human sentiment*? The ignorant common folk, unwittingly ensnared in the web of law—if every matter is handled by precedent, how can the people endure it? Moreover, as you oversee the judicial authority, can you guarantee that local officials never wrongly condemn the innocent? And with your excessive self-assurance, when cases border on the ambiguous, you decide them by your own judgment—how many among them might be blameless yet executed? Measured against the sage’s principle of *when in doubt, punish lightly*, this seems not the way. *"When the waters are too clear, there are no fish"*—this is of your own making, so it is no wonder that Heaven’s Dao has misaligned your fate."

Fei fell silent, deeply regretting his ways.

The god then consoled him: "Throughout your life, you have been upright and impartial. In the future, you and I shall share the same official bond, honored with offerings in this region—what need have you of descendants?" With that, he ordered an underling to escort Fei home.

Upon waking, Fei’s desire for an heir finally ceased. He ultimately adopted his nephew as his successor. On his deathbed, he saw before his couch what appeared to be those seeking redress for grievances. When he rebuked them, they revealed themselves as six bandits from his tenure as judicial commissioner in a certain province—men whose crimes did not warrant death, yet whom he had condemned by the letter of the law. Knowing his end was near, Fei called for his robes and cap, donned them, and passed away. Later, it was said he became the City God of that prefecture.

Long ago, there was an official named Zhang, who served as judicial commissioner in Henan. In every case, he enforced the law with unyielding severity, showing no leniency—especially to the powerful or the sons of wealthy families. At the time, the prohibition against heterodox teachings was strictly enforced. A rich man was accused by his neighbor of practicing such teachings with seditious intent. Hearing of his wealth, Zhang arrested and harshly tortured him. The prefect and the provincial inspector, aware of the false accusation, pleaded his case to Zhang. Zhang merely scoffed, "Is that so?"

Brigadier Chen Dayong submitted an urgent memorial to the throne, though in haste he omitted the governor-general’s title. He accepted the bribe and was determined to overturn the verdict. At that time, a certain prefect of Yangzhou, recently promoted from censor to an external post, paid his respects to the governor-general. The governor-general mentioned the case, hinting at doubts. Your Excellency should investigate thoroughly to avoid wronging the common folk.” The governor-general was delighted and immediately entrusted the case to him.

The governor-general then executed Tianxiang at the coastal port. The brigadier, accused of shielding his subordinate, was stripped of his rank and exiled to the military frontier. The day after Tianxiang’s death, the governor-general went to offer incense. As he was about to mount his sedan, he suddenly rebuked his attendants: “Master Yang has arrived—why did you not announce him?” He turned and walked away as if accompanying a guest. Upon reaching the flower hall, he first made bowing gestures, his lips murmuring as though arguing with someone. Then he began grappling with the air, striking himself across both cheeks until they swelled. After a long while, he cried out, “I was wrong to take the bandits’ gold and let you die! I deserve death! I shall repay your life!” He tore at his own hair, then said, “Stop pulling! I’m going! I’m going!” With that, he dashed his head against a pillar, brains spilling out as he died. At once, all knew it was Tianxiang exacting vengeance.

A year later, the bandit suddenly appeared at the Shandong governor’s yamen to surrender, confessing in detail how he had been captured in Jiangnan and bribed his way to freedom. The governor, unwilling to stir up a major case, executed the bandit while suppressing the matter. Only the Yangzhou prefect ultimately ended his career in honor. For the prefect had always been upright; in reviewing this case, he had not deliberately curried favor with the governor-general. Rather, having long served in the capital, he was all too familiar with the cowardice of provincial Green Standard troops and their habit of framing the innocent to claim merit. Thus, his stubborn prejudice led to this miscarriage of justice. His error was unintentional, so retribution did not fall upon him—yet his reputation never flourished. Moreover, in the year of Tianxiang’s death, a son was born to him, wild and unruly, nearly ruining the family.

The prefect shared years of friendship with my family. I often saw him recounting his chronicle, still claiming this case as a wrong righted. The Master of Sitting Among Flowers said: “From childhood, I knew well the injustice of this case. In my later years, while traveling briefly to Loudong, elders told me: ‘Tianxiang and the brigadier had long been beloved by the troops. Under the established regulations, officials of the sixth rank and below—including assistant and miscellaneous functionaries—as well as those awaiting appointment in educational posts, were exempted from presenting themselves at the Ministry of Personnel to submit credentials. Instead, they were selected in turn through the standard examination process. Once assigned a vacancy, their documents were forwarded by the governor or governor-general of their native province, a measure designed to show consideration and spare minor officials the hardship of travel and the burden of waiting. The intent was most commendable.

Yet those awaiting appointment, unaware of the selection schedule, might serve as private secretaries in another province, relocate with their families, or even fall ill or die without filing a report. After a vacancy was filled, repeated inquiries might yield no trace of them, leaving many posts unoccupied.

When a certain gentleman from Fujian served as Director of Selection, his younger brother, having qualified under the same regulations, found his name placed too far down the list to secure a post. The Director then proposed a new rule: candidates for educational posts awaiting appointment must annually submit a sworn statement from their native prefecture and county, attested by the local authorities and forwarded through the governor or governor-general to the Ministry, confirming their presence in the province and absence of misconduct. Only then would they be eligible for selection. If a candidate ranked higher on the list failed to submit the required documents, the next eligible candidate—even if lower in rank—would be appointed out of turn.

Once the rule was enacted, the Director urged his brother to return home and file the statement. At the time, no other province was aware of the change, and his brother’s documents arrived first. Thus, he leapfrogged the list and secured the post.

Yet for those awaiting appointment, each sworn statement meant another round of exactions. The poor, though aware that the selection period had arrived, often found themselves utterly without resources and unable to comply. Many thus delayed their submission. Those residing in their hometowns or traveling afar were further hindered by their ignorance of the new requirement.

**17. The Righteous Dog**

Yet in disaster’s wake, it seemed to grieve its debt unpaid.

**18. The Grateful Swine**

A strange tale from He Laibai:
*An official’s procession blocked—*
*How odd! In Changzhou, Magistrate Lü Youxin*
*Received deep kindness, repaid it with death—*
*One envies such swine, surpassing men.*

Magistrate Lü Youxin of Changzhou served as Assistant Prefect of Eastern Defense in our Hangzhou. One day, while traveling in his sedan, two swine suddenly prostrated themselves before his palanquin, lifting their heads in a plea for mercy. Whipped, they did not move; driven away, they would not leave. Greatly astonished, he halted the procession and ordered his attendants to investigate their origin. Soon, a butcher was brought forth, who explained that both swine had been purchased from a farming household days prior and were to be slaughtered that very day. They had escaped, he said, never expecting them to disrupt the official’s procession. At the sight of the butcher, the swine cowered even lower, trembling violently, their pitiful cries unceasing. Moved by compassion, Magistrate Lü turned to the butcher and said, “Give the swine to me, and I shall pay you their original price.” He immediately ordered the money fetched, paid the full sum, and took the swine back to the yamen, where they were kept in a pen.

The next morning, as the magistrate rose and entered the front courtyard, the two swine prostrated themselves before him, bowing their heads as if in obeisance. When he shouted at them to leave, they retreated a few paces but remained standing, watching as he entered the inner chambers before returning to their pen. From then on, every dawn they would wait in the front courtyard, bowing as before whenever he emerged. If he returned from outside, they would hear the distant sound of gongs and leap joyfully, as if in welcome.

After leaving office, he called to them, saying, “I am returning home now! I have kept you for years and cannot bear to see you slaughtered again. I shall send you to the Temple of Liberated Life.” The swine hesitated, uttering mournful cries, as if unwilling. Sensing their reluctance, he comforted them, “You do not wish to leave me? Then I shall take you home—how would that be?” The swine immediately bowed their heads, and he brought them back to Changzhou, where they were kept for over a decade. When the magistrate passed away, the two swine wailed day and night, refusing all food. Within days, they starved to death.

21. Magistrate Li Xiaolin

Why seek to flatter and display one’s talent?
For leniency and severity must ever be balanced in governance.
Behold the stern magistrate of Qingyang—
Even when he cried, “I was wrong!” it was already too late.

Magistrate Li Xiaolin, a *mingfu* (a term for county magistrates), had passed the provincial examination as a *jieyuan* (top scholar) before assuming office in Wanjing (present-day Anhui). His literary grace and charismatic bearing won the admiration of his peers. Yet his nature inclined toward severity. While awaiting his post in the provincial capital, he spent his days adjudicating cases at the governor’s yamen. At the time, both the governor-general and the provincial governor favored strict governance, and Xiaolin deliberately curried their favor, ensuring his rulings were harsh and unyielding. His eloquence was sharp, his judgments swift as flowing water. Once he had settled a case, even veteran clerks could find no grounds for objection. Thus, he won the full approval of the governor and governor-general, and in all matters, he leaned toward severity.

A young man of Jiaxing named Zhu had ancestors from Huizhou. As a child, he was bright and fond of reading, but after losing his parents in adolescence, he abandoned his studies. A fellow villager, having established a large shop in Jiaxing, took Zhu along to apprentice in trade. All apprentices regarded the shopkeeper as their master. Zhu was diligent, quick-witted, and sincere, and his master cherished him deeply. Once his training was complete, through frugality and hard work, he amassed a hundred taels of silver. He had long been betrothed and now planned to return home to marry. His master approved but, considering his meager savings, added another hundred taels, set a departure date, and saw him off.

Zhu returned within ten days, astonishing his master with his swift return. He explained that bandits had robbed him mid-journey, leaving him penniless. Realizing there was no point in returning empty-handed, he resolved to wait a year or two, save a little more, and then make another attempt. His master, hearing this, sighed deeply for some time, unaware that Zhu had not been robbed at all.

On his southward journey, Zhu disembarked at a certain place and traveled overland. That night, he lodged at an inn and heard bitter weeping from the next room. Listening closely, he discerned two women sobbing without cease until dawn. At daybreak, he asked the innkeeper about it.

As dawn approached and he prepared to cast off the mooring line, a fierce wind suddenly arose, preventing the boat from advancing. Restless and idle, he gazed absently from the bow. At dusk, just as in his dream, a man arrived carrying over ten volumes of old books for sale. Recalling the previous night’s vision, he purchased them for a hundred coins and, indeed, found two hand-copied volumes among them. Upon inspection, they appeared to be the very *shiwen* he had been told of. The final volume contained only five-character regulated verse. He mused, “The dream has come true—I should copy these at once and return to Hangzhou instead of proceeding onward.” Then, suddenly chuckling to himself, he thought, “How could an unlearned man possibly pass the examination? I’d only invite ridicule. Besides, the second and third sessions of the provincial examination require classical texts, policy essays, and discourses—these two volumes may not contain them all. How could I complete the entire examination?” Resolved, he decided to wait for the wind to subside before continuing his journey.

No sooner had he settled his mind than weariness overtook him. Sitting down, he dozed off, and once again, the two scholars appeared in his dream. “Why so doubtful?” they asked. “If you fear you cannot compose the classical texts or policy essays, there are two bundles of books at the old shop west of the post station. The first volume on the eastern side contains the classical texts, while the third and fourth on the western side are the policy essays. All this year’s topics are included, even the supplementary essays—hurry and purchase them before it’s too late!” The younger one patted his shoulder and said, “Do not bring ruin upon yourself. Next year’s metropolitan examination topics are all here as well!”

He awoke, even more astonished. Following their instructions, he went to the shop west of the post station and, as foretold, found the volumes of classical texts and policy essays. He bought them and returned, though his heart remained filled with doubt. It was early in the seventh month, the heat still oppressive, and sleep eluded him. As he perused the purchased books, he came upon a volume titled *Records of Karmic Retribution in the Examination Halls*, which mentioned cases of candidates passing despite submitting blank papers. His heart stirred, and he thought, “If I follow the dream’s guidance, might I not be like them?” Yet he dared not fully believe it.

Exhausted at last, he fell asleep, and the two scholars reappeared, admonishing him, “If you still do not trust us, we shall summon your father.” Before they finished speaking, his father indeed arrived. The *shangshe* bowed in greeting, but his father glared at him in anger and said, “The underworld holds examination success in the highest regard. I regret not having taught you to read while I was alive. Now, thanks to the efforts of these two gentlemen, the Emperor has bestowed upon you this opportunity. Yet you would squander a ready-made *juren* and *jinshi* degree—what else do you intend to do, unfilial son?” Trembling, the *shangshe* replied, “I shall return to Hangzhou at once and think no more of it.” His father nodded. “That is the proper course.” Then, pointing to the old man, he said, “This is your sister’s father-in-law, and the younger one is her husband.” The *shangshe* finally understood. Before he could speak further, his father added, “Apply yourself well, so that your father may receive an imperial honor and bring glory to the grave.” With that, he pushed him awake.

**24. Tao Shun**

A servant’s duty is to serve his master’s will—
how could he stain his name with lust and theft?
Yet unrepentant, he falsely blamed a beggar still;
how could the courts of darkness suffer such deceit?

Tao Shun was a servant to my great-uncle, the late Minister Yao Wenxi. When Minister Wenxi held office in the capital, my great-grandfather remained at home and entrusted Tao Shun with guarding the gate. Shun carried on an affair with a maidservant and would steal his master’s belongings to sell for money to give her. Once, a single quilt went missing from the study where my four maternal uncles resided—it was Shun who had taken it. The study stood near the side gate, which he often passed through. Just then, a beggar arrived outside the gate seeking alms, and Shun falsely accused him of the theft. When the beggar protested, Shun hastily rallied the other servants to surround and beat him, releasing him only after his injuries grew severe. The beggar died within days.

**25. The Thief Officer Struck by Lightning**
*Greed stirred in midstream, a thief’s heart arose—*
*Grief came when the great tiller crushed the boat below.*
*By dawn, his accomplices all met heavenly doom—*
*Never say there are no gods, for gods there are.*

When the Guangdong rebels crossed the river to occupy Guazhou and Zhenjiang, the commanding general assembled a naval force at Jiaoshan to block their escape from the river into the sea. Among the troops was one Li, a former helmsman of a small boat who had risen through the ranks to the rank of *bazong* through long service. Arrogant and unrestrained, he was often involved in nighttime raids on the southern embankment.

In the winter of *bingchen*, an elderly couple from Yangzhou was traveling south with their family aboard a fishing boat, sailing swiftly downstream. As they passed Li’s vessel, he hooked their boat and, under the pretext of an inspection, led his men aboard to search. They overturned baskets and emptied chests, seizing over two hundred taels of silver and a casket full of gold and silver jewelry. The couple protested and repeatedly demanded its return. Li threatened them, and the old man, frightened, first begged to keep the jewelry in exchange for the silver, then offered to surrender everything if only they would spare their travel funds—both requests were refused. Enraged, the old man cried, “Has the world truly turned upside down? Is there no justice left in heaven?” He turned the boat, untied the mooring rope, and set off.

**27. Thunder’s Warning Against Filial Impiety**
The aged and widowed are pitiable souls,
Yet curses and abuse show too little kin.
A warning without execution has its cause—
For he who herds ducks is but a coarse man.

In Jiangyou, a certain Jia made his living herding ducks. His father was old and widowed—*mào* (aged) and *guān* (widower; as in *Mencius*: ‘Old and without a wife is called *guān*’)—and Jia, resenting his father’s idleness, would constantly revile and humiliate him. One day, as he rained down abuse, a sudden thunderclap struck, and Jia was lifted and thrown to his knees in the courtyard. The villagers rushed to see him—his beard, brows, clothes, and trousers all scorched by the lightning’s fire, his spirit and soul dazed, speechless and motionless. Among them was one who could decipher thunder-script, who urged them to quickly overturn the cauldron and look beneath. Following his advice, they found red seal-script characters inscribed there, which read: *Thunder’s Warning Against Filial Impiety*. The villagers pooled their funds to sponsor a *jiào* (a Daoist ritual for prayer and repentance) and carried Jia to kneel before his father. After three days of the ritual, he regained his speech. From then on, he reformed his ways, and the village called him a filial son.

Once, while traveling on the road, he came upon a corpse lying naked by the wayside. Moved with pity, Marshal Xiao ordered his servant to bury it by the road, and he even removed the red felt mat he had been sitting on to wrap the body.

In the *xinyou* year’s provincial examination, an examiner in his assigned hall received Marshal Xiao’s paper and was about to discard it. Suddenly, he saw something standing upright before his desk—its entire body was red, yet its face, hands, and feet were indistinguishable. Greatly alarmed, he suspected the discarded paper bore some hidden cause and retrieved it to review again. Finding it unremarkable, he resolved to discard it once more, only for the red figure to reappear before him. Three times he cast it aside, and three times it manifested. At last, he recommended the paper to the chief examiner, who sternly reprimanded him. The examiner remained silent, offering no explanation.

That night, the chief examiner also saw a red apparition moving about his desk. The next day, he recounted this to others. Someone familiar with the examiner’s rejection of the paper informed the chief examiner, who nodded in acknowledgment. That evening, the red figure again stood before him. Tentatively, he retrieved the paper and reviewed it—only for the apparition to vanish. When he placed it among the rejected papers, the figure reappeared as before. With no other recourse, he ranked it last among the successful candidates.

After the results were announced, the examiner questioned Marshal Xiao, who could offer no explanation. Upon returning home and recounting the matter to his servant, the servant replied, “Could this be the corpse you buried by the roadside that day?” Marshal Xiao asked, “Why was its entire body red?” The servant answered, “Did you not remove the red felt mat you were sitting on to wrap it? How could you have forgotten?” Marshal Xiao was struck with sudden realization.

Later, through the *datiao* selection, Marshal Xiao was appointed magistrate of a county in Jiangsu, where he earned the epithet “Blue Sky Xiao.” He rose to the rank of Vice Prefect of Suzhou. **29. The Shaanxi Scholar**

Was that fodder-cutter real or not?
His trembling heart still boasted of wrestling ghosts’ might.
A jest turned to no good end—
The wronged soul seized the chance to claim his life.

A certain scholar from Shaanxi studied the legalist arts of Shen Buhai and Han Fei. In his youth, he once misapplied a legal precedent, wrongly condemning a man to death. Ever after, he lived in dread, often recounting the tale to others, fearing that karmic retribution was inescapable.

Later, he accepted a teaching post in a county, where many of his colleagues delighted in telling ghost stories. The scholar, priding himself on his courage, declared that if evil ghosts truly existed, he would seize them with his bare hands. His companions sought a way to test his boldness.

As a banquet was soon to be held, they arrived early at a post station outside the city, where they found no one about. Only in the stables did they encounter a fodder-cutter, his face gaunt and sallow, his frame tall and dark, exuding an eerie presence. The group whispered among themselves, “This man will serve to test the scholar.” They approached him and said, “Tomorrow, we will have someone hide you beneath the bed. After the scholar falls asleep, you are to creep out and lift the bed-curtain to startle him. Can you do this?” The man replied, “I can.” “If you succeed, we will reward you handsomely.” His face brightened with evident delight.

The next day, after the feast concluded and the second watch had begun, the scholar returned to his room and lay down. His companions concealed themselves beneath the window to watch in secret. After a short while, the man emerged from under the bed. Instead of immediately lifting the curtain, he struck his chest and pounded his breast, his ghostly aura chilling the air. The onlookers were all filled with doubt.

Master Cai Xiaoxia, while serving as provincial governor of Shaanxi (as the *Book of Songs* says, *"The noble man is a fence, the great state a screen"*—here meaning he held the office of provincial treasurer in Shaanxi), had a subordinate magistrate who, due to old age and illness, petitioned for retirement. This magistrate had misappropriated three thousand taels from the public treasury, a deficit later exposed by his successor. At the time, the laws were exceedingly strict: embezzlement of even a few hundred taels resulted in confiscation of property and imprisonment to compel repayment. If the debt remained unpaid by the deadline, the penalty was death. The magistrate had been incorruptible in office, and after retirement, he possessed scarcely a single tael. Moreover, he was upright and aloof, with few connections (as the *Book of Later Han* says of Wang Fu, *"unyielding and unswayed by worldly customs"*), and among his colleagues, none could be relied upon for aid. He could only await his doom in silent resignation.

Governor Cai, learning of his plight, took pity on him. The next day, he summoned the magistrate and, dismissing all attendants, said to him: *"I know you lack the means to repay the three thousand taels you owe. Prepare a memorial requesting resolution, and I will endorse it to close the case."* The magistrate, stunned, replied, *"I dare not."* The governor smiled and said, *"I do not jest. I pity your integrity and the fact that you were wronged in service to the public. I intend to use my rightful salary to make up the deficit for you. However, this matter cannot be resolved in a day, so I wish first to endorse your memorial to spare you the hardship of prolonged detention."* The magistrate, overwhelmed by this unexpected kindness, could not speak; he kowtowed and withdrew.

The following day, he submitted the memorial as instructed. Governor Cai personally inscribed the date of repayment, affixed his seal, and returned it to him. The magistrate, dressed in his court robes, entered to express his gratitude. Kneeling, he declared in a loud voice: *"I owe you a debt of rebirth. I am old now and can never repay you in this life—after death, I will beg to be reborn in your family to repay this great kindness."* He then departed.

Over a decade later, Governor Cai also retired and returned to his hometown.

**33. The Murdered Maid’s Vengeance**

A wife of a wealthy household in Hangzhou was exceedingly arrogant and fierce. She treated her maidservants with brutal cruelty; the slightest displeasure would leave them flogged until their skin was shredded. Once, she beat a maid to death with a rod. Her mother-in-law, upon hearing of this, sternly reprimanded her, but she refused to repent. Later, she even resorted to the punishment of *paoluo*—roasting with hot iron!

One day, a maid displeased her. Enraged, she heated an iron in blazing coals until it glowed red, stripped the maid naked, and branded her flesh until her entire body was scorched and blistered. The maid shrieked in agony before dying. Within days, the mistress fell into a mad frenzy. The two maids possessed her body, demanding their lives in return. At times, she tore out her own hair; at others, she slapped her own face. Needles pierced her, blades slashed her—all mirroring the torments she had inflicted upon them.

Her mother-in-law came to question her. The possessed woman knelt and addressed her as "Old Mistress," saying, *"Though we are dead, we dare not forget your kindness."* The mother-in-law urged them to abandon their vengeance and promised to invite eminent monks to perform rites for their salvation. The maids refused, saying, *"Had the young mistress heeded your words, we would not have died unjustly. Before you, Old Mistress, we dare not be disrespectful—but we cannot delay her death."* Thereafter, whenever the mother-in-law visited, the woman’s demeanor would briefly clear. Once the mother-in-law departed, the torment resumed, until at last they claimed her life.

---

**34. The Headless Men**

Great crimes demand meticulous investigation; though the execution date draws near, one must not act in haste. A village headman is no match for a grand marshal—how pitiful that the lowly pay for the sins of the mighty.

In the autumn of the *bingchen* year, a vast army gathered in Danyang. Grand Marshal Xiang, the Loyal and Martial Duke, perished in the camp. Governor Yiyue of the Imperial Residence, traveling from Changzhou to assume command, was met by six military officers from Guangxi. Acting on their commander’s orders, they escorted him back. Passing through Lǚchéng, their boat clashed with a civilian vessel. The six officers, wielding their authority, leapt aboard the civilian boat with drawn blades. They struck a man into the water with the flat of their swords and plundered the silver aboard.

The civilians cried out for help. At that moment, the militia of Lǚchéng had gathered along both banks, awaiting the grand marshal’s arrival. Hearing the shouts from the river, they rushed to the scene. The six officers fought desperately with their weapons. Mistaking them for bandits, the militia overpowered them, killing three and binding the remaining three. By then, the crowd had surged forward, blades and cudgels raining down. Reason was no longer possible—they slew all three captives. Only two boatmen managed to slip away and flee, rushing to report the incident to their commander.

At that time, the magistrate of Dānyáng was a certain *Sīmǎ* (a title equivalent to *tóngzhī*, or vice-magistrate), who had been acting in the post for a year. He posted a hefty reward for their capture. Within twenty days, five of the criminals were seized, but one, Jīn Ādé, remained at large. The wing commander insisted on the principle of "a life for a life," and no exception could be made for the missing man. Ādé’s elder brother, who served as the village head (*lǐzhèng*, or local constable) of Lǚchéng, had been in the city to deliver the other prisoners. The case was thus closed, and the *Sīmǎ* handed over his seal before returning to the provincial capital. No sooner had he arrived at his residence than he fell ill. On the day of his death, a maidservant emerged from the *Sīmǎ*’s bedchamber and saw the long-bearded man leading the headless ghost straight into the room. She screamed and collapsed to the ground. Those keeping vigil rushed in upon hearing her cries, but by the time the maidservant revived, the *Sīmǎ* had already passed away.

The Master of the Flowery Couch remarked: "When matters arise suddenly, the lives of common folk hang in the balance. Those who govern (*sīmù*, referring to officials at all levels) should argue on principle, plead for the people’s lives, and strive for the highest good. Her stepson, however, was deeply filial; in all things, he sought to please his stepmother. As he grew older, he apprenticed at a money shop, and whatever he earned, he dutifully offered to her—only to incur her ever-greater resentment.

One day, she steamed rice cakes and called her eldest son home to eat them. Suddenly, a thunderclap resounded, and she was flung to her knees in the courtyard, still clutching the cakes. **Three Eight: Gu Yunqiao**

*Three branches of the jade tree snapped in grief—*
*To turn from one’s roots, to forsake one’s kin, is to invite such retribution.*
*Ghosts may hunger, but mortal lives are fleeting;*
*For another’s sake, one must not sever another’s line.*

Gu Yunqiao’s father was originally the son of the Liuhe Cheng clan but was adopted into the Gu family. By Yunqiao’s generation, the Cheng lineage had no heir. Relatives from both families agreed that Yunqiao had an elder brother, born of the main wife, who should have carried on the Gu line, while Yunqiao himself ought to have returned to the Cheng clan—both by ritual and by law, this would have been proper. But Yunqiao, unwilling to inconvenience his own interests, refused.

Thus, the sacrifices to the Cheng ancestors were cut off entirely. At the time, Yunqiao had three sons, all bright and promising, with hopes of future success. His eldest son, having just passed twenty, was about to marry when he suddenly fell ill. In his sickness, he saw several men and women demanding sacrifices from him, and he descended into madness. He would cry out for Yunqiao, reproaching him for forsaking his roots and abandoning his kin. All who witnessed this knew the Cheng ancestors’ ghosts were exacting vengeance. They urged Yunqiao to marry off his eldest son and restore him to the Cheng clan, but Yunqiao still refused. The eldest son soon died.

Yunqiao then arranged marriages for his two younger sons, his uncle’s second and third children. Within a year, both sons perished in succession. Yunqiao had each of their widowed wives bear a grandson, but one of them died young. Soon after, Yunqiao himself followed them to the grave. Now, only one young grandson remains, already afflicted with spitting blood. Whether this fragile thread of descent will endure—whether the gods and spirits will secretly aid him—remains unseen.

**40. The Great Stone Lad**

*Where the cowherd once sought the Dragon King’s grace,*
*All praise the mighty Stone Lad of Chongming’s place.*
*When floods threatened Liu River’s shore,*
*Two lands owed him incense evermore.*

The Great Stone Lad was a native of Chongming. Of forthright bearing, great strength, and courage, he was especially fond of releasing living creatures. In his youth, he herded cattle by the sea, and whenever he came upon shrimp, snails, clams, or mussels, he would gather and release them, never killing so much as a single creature.

Once, a large clam rode the tide ashore and settled on the sand. With every opening and closing of its shell, a dazzling radiance flashed forth, growing even more brilliant at night. Onlookers all declared it must contain a luminous pearl, and that whoever obtained it would gain untold wealth. They clamored to split it open and seize the treasure, but the Great Lad refused, saying, “It is a numinous being—it must not be harmed.”
